<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in East Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"People's Republic of China" redirects here. For the Republic of China, see <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"PRC" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/PRC_(disambiguation)" title="PRC (disambiguation)">PRC (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/China_(disambiguation)" title="China (disambiguation)">China (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, href="#cite_note-IMFWEOCN-19">[12]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">72nd</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" countries by Human Development Index">79th</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">Renminbi</a> (元/¥)<sup class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li>yyyy-mm-dd</li><li><i>or</i> yyyy<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">年</span></span>m<span title="Chinese-language text"><span and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_China" title="Telephone numbers in China">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_China" title="Telephone numbers in China">+86</a> (Mainland)<br/><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Hong_Kong" href="/wiki/.cn" title=".cn">.cn</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD" title=".中国">.中国</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B" class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF" title=".香港">.香港</a> (Hong Kong)</li></ul></div><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.mo" title=".mo">.mo</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E6%BE%B3%E9%97%A8" title=".澳门">.澳门</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E6%BE%B3%E9%96%80" title=".澳門">.澳門</a> (Macau)</li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>China</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[i]</a></sup> officially the <b>People's Republic of China</b> (<b>PRC</b>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[j]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>. It is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">most populous country</a> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Population_of_China" title="Population of China">population</a> exceeding 1.4 billion people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[k]</a></sup> China spans five geographical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Time_zones" title="Time zones">time zones</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[l]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_China" title="Borders of China">borders</a> fourteen countries by land,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[m]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_land_borders" title="List of countries and territories by land borders">most of any country</a> in the world, tied with <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>. China also has a narrow <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_maritime_boundaries" title="List of countries and territories by maritime boundaries">maritime boundary</a> with the disputed <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaiwanClaim_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-TaiwanClaim-28">[n]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[o]</a></sup> Covering an area of approximately 9.6 million square kilometers (3,700,000 sq mi), it is the world's third <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">largest country</a> by total land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[p]</a></sup> The country consists of 22 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaiwanClaim_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-TaiwanClaim-28">[n]</a></sup> five <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a>, four <a href="/wiki/Direct-administered_municipalities_of_China" title="Direct-administered municipalities of China">municipalities</a>, and two <a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">Special Administrative Regions</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>). The national capital is <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">most populous</a> city and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">financial center</a> is <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>.
</p><p>Modern Chinese trace their origins to a <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">cradle of civilization</a> in the fertile basin of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in the <a href="/wiki/North_China_Plain" title="North China Plain">North China Plain</a>. The semi-legendary <a href="/wiki/Xia_dynasty" title="Xia dynasty">Xia dynasty</a> in the 21st century BCE and the well-attested <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou</a> dynasties developed a bureaucratic political system to serve hereditary monarchies, or <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">dynasties</a>. <a href="/wiki/Written_Chinese" title="Written Chinese">Chinese writing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_classics" title="Chinese classics">Chinese classic literature</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Schools_of_Thought" title="Hundred Schools of Thought">Hundred Schools of Thought</a> emerged during this period and influenced <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_cultural_sphere" title="East Asian cultural sphere">China and its neighbors</a> for centuries to come. In the third century BCE, <a href="/wiki/Qin%27s_wars_of_unification" title="Qin's wars of unification">Qin's wars of unification</a> created the first Chinese empire, the short-lived <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">Qin dynasty</a>. The Qin was followed by the more stable <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> (206 BCE – 220 CE), which established a model for nearly two millennia in which the Chinese empire was one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_by_past_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of regions by past GDP (PPP)">foremost economic powers</a>. The empire expanded, fractured and re-unified, was conquered and reestablished, absorbed foreign religions and ideas, and made world-leading scientific advances, such as the <a href="/wiki/Four_Great_Inventions" title="Four Great Inventions">Four Great Inventions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">paper</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Printing" title="Printing">printing</a>. After centuries of disunion following <a href="/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="End of the Han dynasty">the fall of the Han</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui</a> (581–618) and <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang</a> (618–907) dynasties reunified the empire. The multi-ethnic Tang welcomed foreign trade and culture that came over the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> and adapted <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> to Chinese needs. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_modern" title="Early modern">early modern</a> <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> (960–1279) became increasingly urban and commercial. The civilian <a href="/wiki/Scholar-official" title="Scholar-official">scholar-official or literati</a> used the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Examination_system" title="Examination system">examination system</a> and  the doctrines of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">Neo-Confucianism</a> to replace the military aristocrats of earlier dynasties. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion" title="Mongol invasion">Mongol invasion</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a> in 1279, but the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> (1368–1644) re-established Han Chinese control. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manchu" title="Manchu">Manchu</a>-led <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> nearly doubled the empire's territory and established a multi-ethnic state that was the basis of the modern Chinese nation, but <a href="/wiki/Century_of_humiliation" title="Century of humiliation">suffered</a> heavy <a href="/wiki/Unequal_treaty" title="Unequal treaty">losses</a> to foreign <a href="/wiki/Imperialism" title="Imperialism">imperialism</a> in the 19th century.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_China" title="Monarchy of China">Chinese monarchy</a> collapsed in 1912 with the <a href="/wiki/1911_Revolution" title="1911 Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a>, when the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a> (ROC) replaced the Qing dynasty. In its <a href="/wiki/Beiyang_government" title="Beiyang government">early years of the Republic</a>, the country became unstable known as the <a href="/wiki/Warlord_Era" title="Warlord Era">Warlord Era</a> before <a href="/wiki/Northern_Expedition" title="Northern Expedition">reunifying</a> the nation in 1928 under the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_government" title="Nationalist government">nationalist government</a> while the alliance between the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (KMT) and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP) had fallen apart that led to a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">civil war</a> that lasted two decades. <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan</a> invaded China in 1937, starting the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> and temporarily halting the civil war. The surrender and expulsion of Japanese forces from China in 1945 left a <a href="/wiki/Power_vacuum" title="Power vacuum">power vacuum</a> in the country, which led to <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution" title="Chinese Communist Revolution">renewed fighting</a> between the CCP and the Kuomintang. The civil war ended in 1949<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[q]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Two_Chinas" title="Two Chinas">division of Chinese territory</a>; the CCP <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People's Republic of China">established</a> the People's Republic of China on the <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland</a> while the Kuomintang-led ROC government <a href="/wiki/Retreat_of_the_government_of_the_Republic_of_China_to_Taiwan" title="Retreat of the government of the Republic of China to Taiwan">retreated</a> to the island of <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan" title="Geography of Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[r]</a></sup> Both claim to be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_China_Policy" title="One China Policy">the sole legitimate government of China</a>, although the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> has <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">recognized the PRC as the sole representation since 1971</a>. From 1959 to 1961, the PRC implemented an economic and social campaign called the <a href="/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward" title="Great Leap Forward">Great Leap Forward</a> that resulted in <a href="/wiki/Great_Chinese_Famine" title="Great Chinese Famine">an estimated 15 to 55 million deaths</a>, mostly through famine. Since then, the Chinese government has rebuked some of the earlier policies, conducting a series of political and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms since 1978</a>, which has greatly raised Chinese standards of living, eliminated absolute poverty and increased life expectancies.
</p><p>China is currently governed as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unitary_State" title="Unitary State">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_republic" title="Socialist republic">socialist republic</a> by the CCP. China is a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and a founding member of several multilateral and regional cooperation organizations such as the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Infrastructure_Investment_Bank" title="Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank">Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_Fund" title="Silk Road Fund">Silk Road Fund</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_Development_Bank" title="New Development Bank">New Development Bank</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership" title="Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership">RCEP</a>, and is a member of the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>. It <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_China" title="International rankings of China">ranks among the lowest</a> in largely Western measurements of <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a>, <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_China" title="Corruption in China">government transparency</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_China" title="Media freedom in China">freedom of the press</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_issues_in_China" title="Ethnic issues in China">freedom of religion and ethnic minorities</a>. The Chinese authorities have been criticized by Western governments and non-governmental organizations for alleged <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">human rights abuses</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">political repression</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">mass censorship</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_China" title="Mass surveillance in China">mass surveillance</a> of their citizens, and violent suppression of protests.
</p><p>China is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">largest economy by GDP</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">second-largest economy by nominal GDP</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_wealth#Total_wealth_by_country" title="List of countries by total wealth">second-wealthiest country</a>. The country is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest growing</a> major economies and is the world's largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_manufacturing_output" title="List of countries by manufacturing output">manufacturer</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">exporter</a>. China is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">recognized nuclear-weapon state</a> with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">largest standing army by military personnel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_China" title="Military budget of China">second-largest defense budget</a>. China is considered to be a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpower#China" title="Potential superpower">potential superpower</a> due to its large markets, high innovation (ranked 11th globally),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[20]</a></sup> economic potential, growing military strength, and influence in international affairs.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-4"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Etymology"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Etymology</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Prehistory"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Prehistory</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Early_dynastic_rule"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Early dynastic rule</span></a></li>

<p><span class="anchor" id="Etymology"></span><span class="anchor" id="Name"></span>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_China" title="Names of China">Names of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg/220px-CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg/330px-CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg/440px-CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CEM-09-Asiae-Nova-Descriptio-China-2510.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>China</i> (today's <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a>), <i>Mangi</i> (inland of <i><a href="/wiki/Shandong" title="Shandong">Xanton</a></i>), and <i>Cataio</i> (inland of <i>China</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Zhejiang" title="Zhejiang">Chequan</a></i>, and including the capital <i><a href="/wiki/Khanbaliq" title="Khanbaliq">Cambalu</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Shangdu" title="Shangdu">Xandu</a></i>, and a <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge" title="Marco Polo Bridge">marble bridge</a>) are all shown as separate regions on this 1570 map by <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Ortelius" title="Abraham Ortelius">Abraham Ortelius</a></div></div></div>
<p>The word "China" has been used in English since the 16th century; however, it was not a word used by the Chinese themselves during this period. Its origin has been traced through <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malays_(ethnic_group)" title="Malays (ethnic group)">Malay</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persian</a> back to the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> word <i>Chīna</i>, used in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_India" title="Ancient India">ancient India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OED_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-OED-39">[21]</a></sup> "China" appears in <a href="/wiki/Richard_Eden_(translator)" title="Richard Eden (translator)">Richard Eden</a>'s 1555 translation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[s]</a></sup> of the 1516 journal of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_empire" title="Portuguese empire">Portuguese</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_exploration" title="Portuguese exploration">explorer</a> <a href="/wiki/Duarte_Barbosa" title="Duarte Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[t]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OED_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-OED-39">[21]</a></sup> Barbosa's usage was derived from <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> <i>Chīn</i> (<span title="Persian-language text"><span lang="fa"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%DA%86%DB%8C%D9%86" title="wikt:چین">چین</a></span></span>), which was in turn derived from Sanskrit <i><a href="/wiki/Chinas" title="Chinas">Cīna</a></i> (<span title="Sanskrit-language text"><span lang="sa"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%9A%E0%A5%80%E0%A4%A8" title="wikt:चीन">चीन</a></span></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AmHer_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-AmHer-46">[26]</a></sup> <i>Cīna</i> was first used in early <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> scripture, including the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81bh%C4%81rata" title="Mahābhārata">Mahābhārata</a></i> (5th century BCE) and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manusm%E1%B9%9Bti" title="Manusmṛti">Laws of Manu</a></i> (2nd century BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wade_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-wade-47">[27]</a></sup> In 1655, <a href="/wiki/Martino_Martini" title="Martino Martini">Martino Martini</a> suggested that the word China is derived ultimately from the name of the <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">Qin dynasty</a> (221–206 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martini_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Martini-48">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wade_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-wade-47">[27]</a></sup> Although usage in Indian sources precedes this dynasty, this derivation is still given in various sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-:9-49">[29]</a></sup> The origin of the Sanskrit word is a matter of debate, according to the <i>Oxford English Dictionary</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OED_39-2"><a href="#cite_note-OED-39">[21]</a></sup> Alternative suggestions include the names for <a href="/wiki/Yelang" title="Yelang">Yelang</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chu_(state)" title="Chu (state)">Jing</a> or Chu state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wade_47-2"><a href="#cite_note-wade-47">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:15_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-:15-50">[30]</a></sup>
The official name of the modern state is the "People's Republic of China" (<a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%8D%8E%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9B%BD" title="wikt:中华人民共和国">中华人民共和国</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9C%8B" title="wikt:中華人民共和國">中華人民共和國</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Zh%C5%8Dnghu%C3%A1_R%C3%A9nm%C3%ADn_G%C3%B2ngh%C3%A9gu%C3%B3" title="wikt:Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó">Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó</a></span></i>). The shorter form is "China" <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Zh%C5%8Dnggu%C3%B3" title="wikt:Zhōngguó">Zhōngguó</a></i> (<span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD" title="wikt:中国">中国</a></span>; <span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B" title="wikt:中國">中國</a></span>) from <i><span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">zhōng</i></span></i> ("central") and <i><span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">guó</i></span></i> ("state"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[u]</a></sup> a term which developed under the <a href="/wiki/Western_Zhou" title="Western Zhou">Western Zhou</a> dynasty in reference to its <a href="/wiki/Demesne" title="Demesne">royal demesne</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[v]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[w]</a></sup> It was then applied to the area around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luoyi" title="Luoyi">Luoyi</a> (present-day Luoyang) during the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Zhou" title="Eastern Zhou">Eastern Zhou</a> and then to China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Plain_(China)" title="Central Plain (China)">Central Plain</a> before being used as an occasional synonym for the state under the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-52">[32]</a></sup> It was often used as a cultural concept to distinguish the <a href="/wiki/Huaxia" title="Huaxia">Huaxia</a> people from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hua-Yi_distinction" title="Hua-Yi distinction">perceived "barbarians"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_52-2"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-52">[32]</a></sup> The name <i>Zhongguo</i> is also translated as <span class="nowrap">"Middle Kingdom"</span> in English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[35]</a></sup> China (PRC) is sometimes referred to as <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">the Mainland</a> when distinguishing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">ROC</a> from the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-:6-59">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-61">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-62">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_China" title="History of China">History of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Chinese_history" title="Timeline of Chinese history">Timeline of Chinese history</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg/220px-National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg/330px-National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg/440px-National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Museum_of_China_2014.02.01_14-43-38.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>10,000 years old pottery, <a href="/wiki/Xianren_Cave" title="Xianren Cave">Xianren Cave</a> culture (18000–7000 BCE)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Archaeological_excavation" title="Archaeological excavation">Archaeological evidence</a> suggests that early <a href="/wiki/Hominidae" title="Hominidae">hominids</a> inhabited China 2.25 million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[40]</a></sup> The hominid fossils of <a href="/wiki/Peking_Man" title="Peking Man">Peking Man</a>, a <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> who <a href="/wiki/Control_of_fire_by_early_humans" title="Control of fire by early humans">used fire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[41]</a></sup> were discovered in a cave at <a href="/wiki/Zhoukoudian" title="Zhoukoudian">Zhoukoudian</a> near <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>; they have been dated to between 680,000 and 780,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">years ago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated198_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated198-65">[42]</a></sup> The fossilized teeth of <i>Homo sapiens</i> (dated to 125,000–80,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">years ago</a>) have been discovered in <a href="/wiki/Fuyan_Cave" title="Fuyan Cave">Fuyan Cave</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dao_County" title="Dao County">Dao County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunan" title="Hunan">Hunan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[43]</a></sup> Chinese <a href="/wiki/Proto-writing" title="Proto-writing">proto-writing</a> existed in <a href="/wiki/Jiahu" title="Jiahu">Jiahu</a> around 6600 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earliest_writing_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-earliest_writing-67">[44]</a></sup> at <a href="/wiki/Damaidi" title="Damaidi">Damaidi</a> around 6000 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[45]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dadiwan_culture" title="Dadiwan culture">Dadiwan</a> from 5800 to 5400 BCE, and <a href="/wiki/Banpo" title="Banpo">Banpo</a> dating from the 5th millennium BCE. Some scholars have suggested that the <a href="/wiki/Jiahu_symbols" title="Jiahu symbols">Jiahu symbols</a> (7th millennium BCE) constituted the earliest Chinese writing system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earliest_writing_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-earliest_writing-67">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_dynastic_rule">Early dynastic rule</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Three_Sovereigns_and_Five_Emperors" title="Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors">Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xia_dynasty" title="Xia dynasty">Xia dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period" title="Spring and Autumn period">Spring and Autumn period</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Warring_States_period" title="Warring States period">Warring States period</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E7%94%B2%E9%AA%A8%E6%96%87%E5%8F%91%E7%8E%B0%E5%9C%B0_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yinxu" title="Yinxu">Yinxu</a>, the ruins of the capital of the late <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a> (14th century BCE)</div></div></div>
<p>According to Chinese tradition, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_dynasties" title="List of Chinese dynasties">first dynasty</a> was the <a href="/wiki/Xia_dynasty" title="Xia dynasty">Xia</a>, which emerged around 2100 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[46]</a></sup> The Xia dynasty marked the beginning of China's political system based on hereditary monarchies, or <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">dynasties</a>, which lasted for a millennium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[47]</a></sup> The Xia dynasty was considered <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">mythical</a> by historians until scientific excavations found early <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> sites at <a href="/wiki/Erlitou_culture" title="Erlitou culture">Erlitou</a>, Henan in 1959.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[48]</a></sup> It remains unclear whether these sites are the remains of the Xia dynasty or of another culture from the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[49]</a></sup> The succeeding <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a> is the earliest to be confirmed by contemporary records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[50]</a></sup> The Shang ruled the plain of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in eastern China from the 17th to the 11th century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[51]</a></sup> Their <a href="/wiki/Oracle_bone_script" title="Oracle bone script">oracle bone script</a> (from <span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1500</span> BCE)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[53]</a></sup> represents the oldest form of Chinese writing yet found<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[54]</a></sup> and is a direct ancestor of modern <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Shang was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou</a>, who ruled between the 11th and 5th centuries BCE, though centralized authority was slowly eroded by feudal warlords. Some principalities eventually emerged from the weakened Zhou, no longer fully obeyed the Zhou king, and continually waged war with each other during the 300-year <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period" title="Spring and Autumn period">Spring and Autumn period</a>. By the time of the <a href="/wiki/Warring_States_period" title="Warring States period">Warring States period</a> of the 5th–3rd centuries BCE, there were only seven powerful states left.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperial_China">Imperial China</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2680" data-file-width="4184" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg/220px-Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg/330px-Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg/440px-Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Badaling_China_Great-Wall-of-China-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China's first emperor, <a href="/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang" title="Qin Shi Huang">Qin Shi Huang</a>, is famed for having united the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warring_States" title="Warring States">Warring States</a>' walls to form the <a href="/wiki/Great_Wall_of_China" title="Great Wall of China">Great Wall of China</a>. Most of the present structure, however, dates to the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Warring States period ended in 221 BCE after the <a href="/wiki/Qin_(state)" title="Qin (state)">state of Qin</a> conquered the other six kingdoms, reunited China and established the dominant order of <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocracy</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Zheng_of_Qin" title="King Zheng of Qin">King Zheng of Qin</a> proclaimed himself the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Emperor" title="First Emperor">First Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">Qin dynasty</a>. He enacted Qin's <a href="/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)" title="Legalism (Chinese philosophy)">legalist</a> reforms throughout China, notably the forced standardization of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_units" title="Chinese units">measurements</a>, road widths (i.e., cart axles' length), and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Chinese_currency" title="History of Chinese currency">currency</a>. His dynasty also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qin%27s_campaign_against_the_Yue_tribes" title="Qin's campaign against the Yue tribes">conquered the Yue tribes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[57]</a></sup> The Qin dynasty lasted only fifteen years, falling soon after the First Emperor's death, as his harsh authoritarian policies led to widespread rebellion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-81">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-82">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a <a href="/wiki/Chu%E2%80%93Han_Contention" title="Chu–Han Contention">widespread civil war</a> during which the imperial library at <a href="/wiki/Xianyang" title="Xianyang">Xianyang</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_destroyed_libraries#Human_action" title="List of destroyed libraries">was burned</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[x]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> emerged to rule China between 206 BCE and CE 220, creating a cultural identity among its populace still remembered in the ethnonym of the <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-81">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-82">[59]</a></sup> The Han <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="History of the Han dynasty">expanded the empire's territory considerably</a>, with military campaigns reaching <a href="/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Xiongnu_War" title="Han–Xiongnu War">Central Asia, Mongolia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gojoseon%E2%80%93Han_War" title="Gojoseon–Han War">South Korea</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Han_campaigns_against_Dian" title="Han campaigns against Dian">Yunnan</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Southward expansion of the Han dynasty">recovery of Guangdong and northern Vietnam</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a>. Han involvement in Central Asia and <a href="/wiki/Sogdia" title="Sogdia">Sogdia</a> helped establish the land route of the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a>, replacing the earlier path over the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> to India. Han China gradually became the largest economy of the ancient world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[61]</a></sup> Despite the Han's initial decentralization and the official abandonment of the Qin philosophy of <a href="/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)" title="Legalism (Chinese philosophy)">Legalism</a> in favor of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, Qin's legalist institutions and policies continued to be employed by the Han government and its successors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Han_Expansion.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="902" data-file-width="1275" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Han_Expansion.png/220px-Han_Expansion.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Han_Expansion.png/330px-Han_Expansion.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Han_Expansion.png/440px-Han_Expansion.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Han_Expansion.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing the expansion of <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in the 2nd century BC</div></div></div>
<p>After the <a href="/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="End of the Han dynasty">end of the Han dynasty</a>, a period of strife known as <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms" title="Three Kingdoms">Three Kingdoms</a> followed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[63]</a></sup> whose central figures were later immortalized in <a href="/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Romance of the Three Kingdoms">one</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_Classics" title="Four Classics">Four Classics</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">Chinese literature</a>. At its end, <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Wei</a> was swiftly overthrown by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265%E2%80%93420)" title="Jin dynasty (265–420)">Jin dynasty</a>. The Jin fell to <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Eight_Princes" title="War of the Eight Princes">civil war</a> upon the ascension of a <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Hui_of_Jin" title="Emperor Hui of Jin">developmentally disabled emperor</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Five_Barbarians" title="Five Barbarians">Five Barbarians</a> then <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uprising_of_the_Five_Barbarians" title="Uprising of the Five Barbarians">invaded</a> and ruled northern China as the <a href="/wiki/Sixteen_Kingdoms" title="Sixteen Kingdoms">Sixteen States</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Xianbei" title="Xianbei">Xianbei</a> unified them as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Wei" title="Northern Wei">Northern Wei</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Xiaowen_of_Northern_Wei" title="Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei">Emperor Xiaowen</a> reversed his predecessors' apartheid policies and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_dynasties" title="Northern dynasties">enforced a drastic sinification on his subjects</a>, largely integrating them into Chinese culture. In the south, the general <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Wu_of_Liu_Song" title="Emperor Wu of Liu Song">Liu Yu</a> secured the abdication of the Jin in favor of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liu_Song" title="Liu Song">Liu Song</a>. The various successors of these states became known as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties" title="Northern and Southern dynasties">Northern and Southern dynasties</a>, with the two areas finally reunited by the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui</a> in 581. The Sui restored the Han to power through China, reformed its agriculture, economy and <a href="/wiki/Imperial_examination" title="Imperial examination">imperial examination</a> system, constructed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_China" title="Grand Canal of China">Grand Canal</a>, and patronized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_China" title="Buddhism in China">Buddhism</a>. However, they fell quickly when their conscription for public works and a <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War" title="Goguryeo–Sui War">failed war</a> in <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">northern Korea</a> provoked widespread unrest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the succeeding <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song</a> dynasties, Chinese economy, technology, and culture entered a golden age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[66]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> retained control of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Regions" title="Western Regions">Western Regions</a> and the Silk Road,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[67]</a></sup> which brought traders to as far as <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[68]</a></sup> and made the capital <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an" title="Chang'an">Chang'an</a> a cosmopolitan urban center. However, it was devastated and weakened by the <a href="/wiki/An_Lushan_Rebellion" title="An Lushan Rebellion">An Lushan Rebellion</a> in the 8th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[69]</a></sup> In 907, the Tang disintegrated completely when the local military governors became ungovernable. The Song dynasty ended the <a href="/wiki/Five_Dynasties_and_Ten_Kingdoms_period" title="Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period">separatist situation</a> in 960, leading to a balance of power between the Song and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khitan_Liao" title="Khitan Liao">Khitan Liao</a>. The Song was the first government in world history to issue paper money and the first Chinese <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polity</a> to establish a permanent standing navy which was supported by the developed shipbuilding industry along with the sea trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tang_Protectorates.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="795" data-file-width="1118" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Tang_Protectorates.png/220px-Tang_Protectorates.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Tang_Protectorates.png/330px-Tang_Protectorates.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Tang_Protectorates.png/440px-Tang_Protectorates.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tang_Protectorates.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Tang dynasty at its greatest extent and Tang's <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Tang_dynasty#Protectorates" title="Administrative divisions of the Tang dynasty">protectorates</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:201px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_(detail_of_original).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1800" data-file-width="3600" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/199px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/299px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/398px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg 2x" width="199"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_(detail_of_original).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A detail from <i><a href="/wiki/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival" title="Along the River During the Qingming Festival">Along the River During the Qingming Festival</a></i>, a 12th-century painting showing everyday life in the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a>'s capital, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bianjing" title="Bianjing">Bianjing</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/Kaifeng" title="Kaifeng">Kaifeng</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Between the 10th and 11th centuries, the population of China doubled in size to around 100 million people, mostly because of the expansion of rice cultivation in central and southern China, and the production of abundant food surpluses. The Song dynasty also saw a <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">revival of Confucianism</a>, in response to the growth of Buddhism during the Tang,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[71]</a></sup> and a flourishing of philosophy and the arts, as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Landscape_art" title="Landscape art">landscape art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porcelain" title="Porcelain">porcelain</a> were brought to new levels of maturity and complexity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[73]</a></sup> However, the military weakness of the Song army was observed by the <a href="/wiki/Jurchen_people" title="Jurchen people">Jurchen</a> <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(1115%E2%80%931234)" title="Jin dynasty (1115–1234)">Jin dynasty</a>. In 1127, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Huizong_of_Song" title="Emperor Huizong of Song">Emperor Huizong of Song</a> and the capital <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bianjing" title="Bianjing">Bianjing</a> were captured during the <a href="/wiki/Jin%E2%80%93Song_Wars" title="Jin–Song Wars">Jin–Song Wars</a>. The remnants of the Song retreated to <a href="/wiki/Northern_and_southern_China" title="Northern and southern China">southern China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_China" title="Mongol conquest of China">Mongol conquest of China</a> began in 1205 with the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_Western_Xia" title="Mongol conquest of Western Xia">gradual conquest</a> of <a href="/wiki/Western_Xia" title="Western Xia">Western Xia</a> by <a href="/wiki/Genghis_Khan" title="Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[75]</a></sup> who also <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Jin_dynasty" title="Mongol conquest of the Jin dynasty">invaded Jin territories</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[76]</a></sup> In 1271, the <a href="/wiki/Mongols" title="Mongols">Mongol</a> <a href="/wiki/Khagan" title="Khagan">leader</a> <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Kublai Khan</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Song_dynasty" title="Mongol conquest of the Song dynasty">conquered the last remnant of the Song dynasty</a> in 1279. Before the Mongol invasion, the population of Song China was 120 million citizens; this was reduced to 60 million by the time of the census in 1300.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[77]</a></sup> A peasant named Zhu Yuanzhang <a href="/wiki/Red_Turban_Rebellions" title="Red Turban Rebellions">led a rebellion</a> that overthrew the Yuan in 1368 and founded the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor" title="Hongwu Emperor">Hongwu Emperor</a>. Under the Ming dynasty, China enjoyed another golden age, developing one of the strongest navies in the world and a rich and prosperous economy amid a flourishing of art and culture. It was during this period that admiral <a href="/wiki/Zheng_He" title="Zheng He">Zheng He</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Ming_treasure_voyages" title="Ming treasure voyages">Ming treasure voyages</a> throughout the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, reaching as far as <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="742" data-file-width="849" decoding="async" height="192" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg/220px-Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg/330px-Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg/440px-Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Qing_Empire_circa_1820_EN.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming" title="Qing conquest of the Ming">Qing conquest of the Ming</a> and expansion of the empire</div></div></div>
<p>In the early years of the Ming dynasty, China's capital was moved from <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> to Beijing. With the budding of capitalism, philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yangming" title="Wang Yangming">Wang Yangming</a> further critiqued and expanded Neo-Confucianism with concepts of <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">individualism</a> and equality of <a href="/wiki/Four_occupations" title="Four occupations">four occupations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[79]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Scholar-official" title="Scholar-official">scholar-official</a> stratum became a supporting force of industry and commerce in the tax boycott movements, which, together with the famines and defense against <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasions_of_Korea_(1592%E2%80%931598)" title="Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)">Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming" title="Qing conquest of the Ming">Manchu invasions</a> led to an exhausted treasury.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[80]</a></sup> In 1644, Beijing was captured by a coalition of peasant rebel forces led by <a href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chongzhen_Emperor" title="Chongzhen Emperor">Chongzhen Emperor</a> committed suicide when the city fell. The Manchu <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>, then allied with Ming dynasty general <a href="/wiki/Wu_Sangui" title="Wu Sangui">Wu Sangui</a>, overthrew Li's short-lived <a href="/wiki/Shun_dynasty" title="Shun dynasty">Shun dynasty</a> and subsequently seized control of Beijing, which became the new capital of the Qing dynasty.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The Qing dynasty, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. Its <a href="/wiki/Transition_from_Ming_to_Qing" title="Transition from Ming to Qing">conquest of the Ming</a> (1618–1683) cost 25 million lives and the <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_before_1912#Qing_dynasty_(1644–1912)" title="Economic history of China before 1912">economy of China shrank drastically</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[81]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ming" title="Southern Ming">Southern Ming</a> ended, the further conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Dzungar_Khanate" title="Dzungar Khanate">Dzungar Khanate</a> added Mongolia, Tibet and Xinjiang to the empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[82]</a></sup> The centralized autocracy was strengthened to suppress <a href="/wiki/Anti-Qing_sentiment" title="Anti-Qing sentiment">anti-Qing sentiment</a> with the policy of valuing agriculture and restraining commerce, the <i><a href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">Haijin</a></i> ("sea ban"), and ideological control as represented by the <a href="/wiki/Literary_inquisition" title="Literary inquisition">literary inquisition</a>, causing social and technological stagnation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fall_of_the_Qing_dynasty">Fall of the Qing dynasty</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Century_of_humiliation" title="Century of humiliation">Century of humiliation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opium_Wars" title="Opium Wars">Opium Wars</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EightNationsCrime02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="511" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/220px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/330px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/440px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EightNationsCrime02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">Eight-Nation Alliance</a> invaded China to defeat the anti-foreign <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxers</a> and their Qing backers. The image shows a celebration ceremony inside the Chinese imperial palace, the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a> after the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Protocol" title="Boxer Protocol">Boxer Protocol</a> in 1901.</div></div></div>
<p>In the mid-19th century, the Qing dynasty experienced Western imperialism in the <a href="/wiki/Opium_Wars" title="Opium Wars">Opium Wars</a> with Britain and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>. China was forced to pay compensation, open treaty ports, allow <a href="/wiki/Extraterritoriality" title="Extraterritoriality">extraterritoriality</a> for foreign nationals, and cede <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> to the British<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[85]</a></sup> under the 1842 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Nanking" title="Treaty of Nanking">Treaty of Nanking</a>, the first of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unequal_Treaties" title="Unequal Treaties">Unequal Treaties</a>. The <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (1894–1895) resulted in Qing China's loss of influence in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Shimonoseki" title="Treaty of Shimonoseki">cession of Taiwan</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japan_Empire" title="Japan Empire">Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[86]</a></sup>
The Qing dynasty also began experiencing <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_late_anti-Qing_rebellions" title="Timeline of late anti-Qing rebellions">internal unrest</a> in which tens of millions of people died, especially in the <a href="/wiki/White_Lotus_Rebellion" title="White Lotus Rebellion">White Lotus Rebellion</a>, the failed <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping Rebellion</a> that ravaged southern China in the 1850s and 1860s and the <a href="/wiki/Dungan_Revolt_(1862%E2%80%931877)" title="Dungan Revolt (1862–1877)">Dungan Revolt (1862–1877)</a> in the northwest. The initial success of the <a href="/wiki/Self-Strengthening_Movement" title="Self-Strengthening Movement">Self-Strengthening Movement</a> of the 1860s was frustrated by a series of military defeats in the 1880s and 1890s.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In the 19th century, the great <a href="/wiki/Chinese_emigration" title="Chinese emigration">Chinese diaspora</a> began. Losses due to emigration were added to by conflicts and catastrophes such as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Chinese_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931879" title="Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–1879">Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–1879</a>, in which between 9 and 13 million people died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[87]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Guangxu_Emperor" title="Guangxu Emperor">Guangxu Emperor</a> drafted a <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days%27_Reform" title="Hundred Days' Reform">reform plan</a> in 1898 to establish a modern <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, but these plans were thwarted by the <a href="/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Cixi" title="Empress Dowager Cixi">Empress Dowager Cixi</a>. The ill-fated anti-foreign <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> of 1899–1901 further weakened the dynasty. Although Cixi sponsored a program of reforms, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a> of 1911–1912 brought an end to the Qing dynasty and established the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[88]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Puyi" title="Puyi">Puyi</a>, the last Emperor of China, abdicated in 1912.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Establishment_of_the_Republic_and_World_War_II">Establishment of the Republic and World War II</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China (1912–1949)</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/1911_Revolution" title="1911 Revolution">1911 Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution" title="Chinese Communist Revolution">Chinese Communist Revolution</a></div><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3147" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg/130px-Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg/195px-Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg/260px-Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Yat-sen_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a>, the founding father of <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a>, one of the first republics in Asia.</div></div></div>
<p>On 1 January 1912, the Republic of China was established, and <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (the KMT or Nationalist Party) was proclaimed provisional president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[90]</a></sup> On 12 February 1912, <a href="/wiki/Regent" title="Regent">regent</a> <a href="/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Longyu" title="Empress Dowager Longyu">Empress Dowager Longyu</a> sealed the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Edict_of_the_Abdication_of_the_Qing_Emperor" title="Imperial Edict of the Abdication of the Qing Emperor">imperial abdication decree</a> on behalf of 4 year old <a href="/wiki/Puyi" title="Puyi">Puyi</a>, the last emperor of China, ending 5,000 years of <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_China" title="Monarchy of China">monarchy in China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[91]</a></sup> In March 1912, the presidency was given to <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shikai" title="Yuan Shikai">Yuan Shikai</a>, a former Qing general who in 1915 proclaimed himself <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_China_(1915%E2%80%931916)" title="Empire of China (1915–1916)">Emperor of China</a>. In the face of popular condemnation and opposition from his own <a href="/wiki/Beiyang_Army" title="Beiyang Army">Beiyang Army</a>, he was forced to abdicate and re-establish the republic in 1916.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Yuan Shikai's death in 1916, China was politically fragmented. Its Beijing-based government was internationally recognized but virtually powerless; regional warlords controlled most of its territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[94]</a></sup> In the late 1920s, the Kuomintang under <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, the then Principal of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Military_Academy" title="Republic of China Military Academy">Republic of China Military Academy</a>, was able to reunify the country under its own control with a series of deft military and political maneuverings, known collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Expedition" title="Northern Expedition">Northern Expedition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[96]</a></sup> The Kuomintang moved the nation's capital to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> and implemented "political tutelage", an intermediate stage of political development outlined in Sun Yat-sen's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San-min_Doctrine" title="San-min Doctrine">San-min</a> program for transforming China into a modern democratic state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[98]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_warlords_and_military_cliques_in_the_Warlord_Era" title="List of warlords and military cliques in the Warlord Era">political division</a> in China made it difficult for Chiang to battle the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Communists" title="Chinese Communists">communist</a>-led <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> (PLA), against whom the Kuomintang had been warring since 1927 in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>. This war continued successfully for the Kuomintang, especially after the PLA retreated in the <a href="/wiki/Long_March" title="Long March">Long March</a>, until Japanese aggression and the 1936 <a href="/wiki/Xi%27an_Incident" title="Xi'an Incident">Xi'an Incident</a> forced Chiang to confront <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_Japan" title="Imperial Japan">Imperial Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1364" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/220px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/330px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/440px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> toasting together in 1945 following the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia" title="End of World War II in Asia">end of World War II</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> (1937–1945), a <a href="/wiki/Theater_(warfare)" title="Theater (warfare)">theater</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, forced an uneasy alliance between the Kuomintang and the Communists. Japanese forces committed numerous <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war atrocities</a> against the civilian population; in all, as many as 20 million Chinese civilians died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[100]</a></sup> An estimated 40,000 to 300,000 Chinese <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nanking_Massacre" title="Nanking Massacre">were massacred</a> in the city of Nanjing alone during the Japanese occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[101]</a></sup> During the war, China, along with the UK, the United States, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, were referred to as "trusteeship of the powerful"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Justus_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-Justus-126">[102]</a></sup> and were recognized as the Allied "<a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">Big Four</a>" in the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_by_United_Nations" title="Declaration by United Nations">Declaration by United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[104]</a></sup> Along with the other three great powers, China was one of the four major <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies of World War II</a>, and was later considered one of the primary victors in the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[106]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrender of Japan</a> in 1945, Taiwan, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pescadores" title="Pescadores">Pescadores</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Retrocession_Day" title="Retrocession Day">handed over to Chinese control</a>. However, the validity of this handover is controversial, in that whether Taiwan's sovereignty was legally transferred and whether China is a legitimate recipient, due to complex issues that arose from the handling of Japan's surrender, resulting in the unresolved <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">political status of Taiwan</a>, which is a flashpoint of potential war between China and Taiwan. China emerged victorious but war-ravaged and financially drained. The continued distrust between the Kuomintang and the Communists led to the resumption of civil war. Constitutional rule was established in 1947, but because of the ongoing unrest, many provisions of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the Republic of China">ROC constitution</a> were never implemented in mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Civil_War_and_the_People.27s_Republic"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War_and_the_People's_Republic">Civil War and the People's Republic</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="History of the People's Republic of China">History of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Soviet_Republic" title="Chinese Soviet Republic">Chinese Soviet Republic</a>; <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People's Republic of China">Proclamation of the People's Republic of China</a>; <a href="/wiki/Retreat_of_the_government_of_the_Republic_of_China_to_Taiwan" title="Retreat of the government of the Republic of China to Taiwan">Retreat of the government of the Republic of China to Taiwan</a>; <a href="/wiki/Taiwan,_China" title="Taiwan, China">Taiwan, China</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1100" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/220px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/330px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/440px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaiming the establishment of the PRC in 1949.</div></div></div>
