<p>Before the existence of the People's Republic, the CCP had declared <a href="/wiki/Communist-controlled_China_(1927%E2%80%931949)" title="Communist-controlled China (1927–1949)">several areas of the country</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Soviet_Republic" title="Chinese Soviet Republic">Chinese Soviet Republic</a> (Jiangxi Soviet), a predecessor state to the PRC, in November 1931 in <a href="/wiki/Ruijin" title="Ruijin">Ruijin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiangxi" title="Jiangxi">Jiangxi</a>. The Jiangxi Soviet was <a href="/wiki/Encirclement_campaigns" title="Encirclement campaigns">wiped out</a> by the KMT armies in 1934 and was relocated to <a href="/wiki/Yan%27an" title="Yan'an">Yan'an</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shaanxi" title="Shaanxi">Shaanxi</a> where the <a href="/wiki/Long_March" title="Long March">Long March</a> concluded in 1935.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[108]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (April 2022)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> It would be the base of the communists before major combat in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> ended in 1949. Afterwards, the CCP gain control of most of <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_retreat_to_Taiwan" title="Republic of China retreat to Taiwan">Kuomintang retreating offshore to Taiwan</a>, reducing its territory to only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwan_(island)" title="Taiwan (island)">Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a>, and their surrounding islands.
</p><p>On 1 October 1949, <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP Chairman</a> <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> formally <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People's Republic of China">proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China</a> at the new nation's founding ceremony and inaugural military parade in <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square" title="Tiananmen Square">Tiananmen Square</a>, Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[110]</a></sup> In 1950, the People's Liberation Army <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Landing_Operation_on_Hainan_Island" title="Landing Operation on Hainan Island">captured Hainan</a> from the ROC<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[111]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Incorporation_of_Tibet_into_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Incorporation of Tibet into the People's Republic of China">incorporated Tibet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[112]</a></sup> However, remaining Kuomintang forces continued to wage <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang_Islamic_insurgency" title="Kuomintang Islamic insurgency">an insurgency in western China</a> throughout the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government consolidated its popularity among the peasants through land reform, which included the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_killings_of_landlords_under_Mao_Zedong" title="Mass killings of landlords under Mao Zedong">execution of between 1 and 2 million landlords</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[114]</a></sup> China developed an independent industrial system and <a href="/wiki/China_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="China and weapons of mass destruction">its own nuclear weapons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[115]</a></sup> The Chinese population increased from 550 million in 1950 to 900 million in 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[116]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward" title="Great Leap Forward">Great Leap Forward</a>, an idealistic massive reform project, resulted in <a href="/wiki/Great_Chinese_Famine" title="Great Chinese Famine">an estimated 15 to 55 million deaths</a> between 1959 and 1961, mostly from starvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-141">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[118]</a></sup> In 1966, Mao and his allies launched the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, sparking a decade of political recrimination and social upheaval that lasted until Mao's death in 1976. In October 1971, the PRC <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">replaced the Republic of China</a> in the United Nations, and took its seat as a permanent member of the Security Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[119]</a></sup> This UN action also created the problem of the <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">political status of Taiwan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Two_Chinas" title="Two Chinas">Two Chinas</a> issue. See <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a> and "<a href="/wiki/Taiwan,_China" title="Taiwan, China">Taiwan, China</a>".
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reforms_and_contemporary_history">Reforms and contemporary history</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">Chinese economic reform</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ud%C3%A1losti_na_n%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD_Tian_an_men,_%C4%8C%C3%ADna_1989,_foto_Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Tondl.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="199" data-file-width="299" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Ud%C3%A1losti_na_n%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD_Tian_an_men%2C_%C4%8C%C3%ADna_1989%2C_foto_Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Tondl.jpg/220px-Ud%C3%A1losti_na_n%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD_Tian_an_men%2C_%C4%8C%C3%ADna_1989%2C_foto_Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Tondl.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e7/Ud%C3%A1losti_na_n%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD_Tian_an_men%2C_%C4%8C%C3%ADna_1989%2C_foto_Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Tondl.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ud%C3%A1losti_na_n%C3%A1m%C4%9Bst%C3%AD_Tian_an_men,_%C4%8C%C3%ADna_1989,_foto_Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Tondl.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1989_Tiananmen_Square_protests" title="1989 Tiananmen Square protests">1989 Tiananmen Square protests</a> was ended by a military-led massacre which brought condemnations and sanctions against the Chinese government from various foreign countries.</div></div></div>
<p>After Mao's death, the <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Four" title="Gang of Four">Gang of Four</a> was quickly arrested by <a href="/wiki/Hua_Guofeng" title="Hua Guofeng">Hua Guofeng</a> and held responsible for the excesses of the Cultural Revolution. <a href="/wiki/Eight_Elders" title="Eight Elders">Elder</a> <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> took power in 1978, and instituted significant <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms</a>. The CCP loosened governmental control over citizens' personal lives, and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_commune" title="People's commune">communes</a> were gradually disbanded in favor of working contracted to households. This marked China's transition from a planned economy to a mixed economy with an <a href="/wiki/Socialist_market_economy" title="Socialist market economy">increasingly open-market environment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_e_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_e-144">[120]</a></sup> China adopted its current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">constitution</a> on 4 December 1982. In 1989, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_at_Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="People's Liberation Army at Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">suppression</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">student protests in Tiananmen Square</a> brought condemnations and sanctions against the Chinese government from various foreign countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jiang_Zemin" title="Jiang Zemin">Jiang Zemin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Li_Peng" title="Li Peng">Li Peng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhu_Rongji" title="Zhu Rongji">Zhu Rongji</a> led the nation in the 1990s. Under their administration, China's economic performance pulled an estimated<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (October 2021)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup> 150 million peasants out of poverty and sustained an average annual gross domestic product growth rate of 11.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[122]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/British_Hong_Kong" title="British Hong Kong">British Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Portuguese Macau</a> returned to China in <a href="/wiki/Handover_of_Hong_Kong" title="Handover of Hong Kong">1997</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_sovereignty_over_Macau" title="Transfer of sovereignty over Macau">1999</a>, respectively, as the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> <a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">special administrative regions</a> under the principle of <a href="/wiki/One_country,_two_systems" title="One country, two systems">One country, two systems</a>. The country joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> in 2001, and maintained its high rate of economic growth under <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wen_Jiabao" title="Wen Jiabao">Wen Jiabao</a>'s leadership in the 2000s. However, the growth also severely impacted the country's resources and environment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[124]</a></sup> and caused <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protest_and_dissent_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Protest and dissent in the People's Republic of China">major social displacement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_k_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_k-149">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>CCP general secretary Xi Jinping has ruled since 2012 and has pursued large-scale efforts to reform China's economy<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC19July2013a_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC19July2013a-151">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[128]</a></sup> (which has suffered from structural instabilities and slowing growth),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[131]</a></sup> and has also reformed the <a href="/wiki/One-child_policy" title="One-child policy">one-child policy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Penal_system_in_China" title="Penal system in China">penal system</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SlateChina2013_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-SlateChina2013-156">[132]</a></sup> as well as instituting a vast <a href="/wiki/Anti-corruption_campaign_under_Xi_Jinping" title="Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping">anti corruption crackdown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[133]</a></sup> In 2013, China initiated the <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a>, a global infrastructure investment project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[134]</a></sup> Since 2017, the Chinese government has been engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_genocide" title="Uyghur genocide">harsh crackdown</a> in Xinjiang, with an estimated one million people, mostly <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghurs</a> but including other ethnic and religious minorities, in internment camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:13_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-:13-159">[135]</a></sup> In 2020, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC) passed a <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_national_security_law" title="Hong Kong national security law">national security law</a> in Hong Kong that gave the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Hong_Kong" title="Government of Hong Kong">Hong Kong government</a> wide-ranging tools to crack down on dissent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The global <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> originated in <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a> and was first identified from an outbreak in December 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[137]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_government_response_to_COVID-19" title="Chinese government response to COVID-19">Chinese government response</a> has included a <a href="/wiki/Zero-COVID" title="Zero-COVID">zero-COVID</a> strategy, making it one of few countries to pursue this approach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[138]</a></sup> The country's economy continued to broaden recovery from the recession during the pandemic, with stable job creation and record international trade growth, although retail consumption was still slower than predicted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[140]</a></sup> On 1 July 2021, the People's Republic of China celebrated the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/100th_anniversary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="100th anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party">100th anniversary</a> of the establishment of the CCP (first of the <a href="/wiki/Two_Centenaries" title="Two Centenaries">Two Centenaries</a>) with a huge gathering in <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square" title="Tiananmen Square">Tiananmen Square</a> and cultural artistic performance in <a href="/wiki/Beijing_National_Stadium" title="Beijing National Stadium">Beijing National Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_China" title="Geography of China">Geography of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:East_Asia_topographic_map.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2094" data-file-width="2876" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/East_Asia_topographic_map.png/220px-East_Asia_topographic_map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/East_Asia_topographic_map.png/330px-East_Asia_topographic_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/East_Asia_topographic_map.png/440px-East_Asia_topographic_map.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:East_Asia_topographic_map.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China topographic map with East Asia countries</div></div></div>
<p>China's landscape is vast and diverse, ranging from the <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan Deserts</a> in the arid north to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">subtropical</a> forests in the wetter south. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Himalaya" title="Himalaya">Himalaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karakoram" title="Karakoram">Karakoram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tian_Shan" title="Tian Shan">Tian Shan</a> mountain ranges separate China from much of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow Rivers</a>, the third- and sixth-longest in the world, respectively, run from the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau" title="Tibetan Plateau">Tibetan Plateau</a> to the densely populated eastern seaboard. China's coastline along the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> is 14,500 km (9,000 mi) long and is bounded by the <a href="/wiki/Bohai_Sea" title="Bohai Sea">Bohai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China</a> seas. China connects through the Kazakh border to the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Steppe" title="Eurasian Steppe">Eurasian Steppe</a> which has been an artery of communication between East and West since the Neolithic through the <a href="/wiki/Steppe_Route" title="Steppe Route">Steppe Route</a> – the ancestor of the terrestrial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silk_Road_UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" title="Silk Road UNESCO World Heritage Sites">Silk Road</a>(s).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The territory of China lies between <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitudes</a> <a href="/wiki/18th_parallel_north" title="18th parallel north">18°</a> and <a href="/wiki/54th_parallel_north" title="54th parallel north">54° N</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitudes</a> <a href="/wiki/73rd_meridian_east" title="73rd meridian east">73°</a> and <a href="/wiki/135th_meridian_east" title="135th meridian east">135° E</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geographical_center" title="Geographical center">geographical center</a> of China is marked by the Center of the Country Monument at <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1073938472" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=China&amp;params=35_50_40.9_N_103_27_7.5_E_region:CN-62_type:landmark&amp;title=Geographical+center+of+China"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">35°50′40.9″N</span> <span class="longitude">103°27′7.5″E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="vcard"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">35.844694°N 103.452083°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">35.844694; 103.452083</span></span><span style="display:none">﻿ (<span class="fn org">Geographical center of China</span>)</span></span></span></a></span>. China's landscapes vary significantly across its vast territory. In the east, along the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>, there are extensive and densely populated <a href="/wiki/Alluvium" title="Alluvium">alluvial plains</a>, while on the edges of the Inner Mongolian plateau in the north, broad <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">grasslands</a> predominate. Southern China is dominated by hills and low mountain ranges, while the central-east hosts the <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">deltas</a> of China's two major rivers, the Yellow River and the Yangtze River. Other major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Xi_River" title="Xi River">Xi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mekong" title="Mekong">Mekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur</a>. To the west sit major mountain ranges, most notably the Himalayas. High <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateaus</a> feature among the more arid landscapes of the north, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi Desert</a>. The world's highest point, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a> (8,848 m), lies on the Sino-Nepalese border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[142]</a></sup> The country's lowest point, and the world's third-lowest, is the dried lake bed of <a href="/wiki/Ayding_Lake" title="Ayding Lake">Ayding Lake</a> (−154 m) in the <a href="/wiki/Turpan_Depression" title="Turpan Depression">Turpan Depression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Great_Green_Wall_(China)" title="Great Green Wall (China)">Great Green Wall (China)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1761" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg/310px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg/465px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg/620px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_CHN_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen-Geiger climate classification</a> map for mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[144]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>China's climate is mainly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry seasons</a> and wet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monsoons" title="Monsoons">monsoons</a>, which lead to pronounced temperature differences between winter and summer. In the winter, northern winds coming from high-latitude areas are cold and dry; in summer, southern winds from coastal areas at lower latitudes are warm and moist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>A major environmental issue in China is the continued <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">expansion of its deserts</a>, particularly the Gobi Desert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[147]</a></sup> Although barrier tree lines planted since the 1970s have reduced the frequency of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sandstorms" title="Sandstorms">sandstorms</a>, prolonged drought and poor agricultural practices have resulted in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_dust" title="Asian dust">dust storms</a> plaguing northern China each spring, which then spread to other parts of East Asia, including Japan and Korea. China's environmental watchdog, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Environmental_Protection_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China">SEPA</a>, stated in 2007 that China is losing 4,000 km<sup>2</sup> (1,500 sq mi) per year to desertification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[148]</a></sup> Water quality, <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pollution_in_China" title="Pollution in China">pollution control</a> have become important issues in China's relations with other countries. Melting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glaciers" title="Glaciers">glaciers</a> in the Himalayas could potentially lead to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_shortage" title="Water shortage">water shortages</a> for hundreds of millions of people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msnbc_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-msnbc-173">[149]</a></sup> According to academics, in order to limit <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_China" title="Climate change in China">climate change in China</a> to 1.5 °C (2.7 °F) electricity generation from <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_China" title="Coal in China">coal in China</a> without <a href="/wiki/Carbon_capture_and_storage" title="Carbon capture and storage">carbon capture</a> must be phased out by 2045.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[150]</a></sup> Official government statistics about Chinese agricultural productivity are considered unreliable, due to exaggeration of production at subsidiary government levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[152]</a></sup> Much of China has a climate very suitable for agriculture and the country has been the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Rice_production_in_China" title="Rice production in China">rice</a>, wheat, tomatoes, eggplant, grapes, watermelon, spinach, and many other crops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[153]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_China" title="Wildlife of China">Wildlife of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/220px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/330px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/440px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Giant_panda" title="Giant panda">giant panda</a>, China's most famous <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China" title="List of endangered and protected species of China">endangered</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> species, at the <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_Research_Base_of_Giant_Panda_Breeding" title="Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding">Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a></div></div></div>
<p>China is one of 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009a_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009a-178">[154]</a></sup> lying in two of the world's major <a href="/wiki/Biogeographic_realm" title="Biogeographic realm">biogeographic realms</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Palearctic_realm" title="Palearctic realm">Palearctic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indomalayan_realm" title="Indomalayan realm">Indomalayan</a>. By one measure, China has over 34,687 species of animals and vascular plants, making it the third-most biodiverse country in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[155]</a></sup> The country signed the <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 11 June 1992, and became a party to the convention on 5 January 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[156]</a></sup> It later produced a <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>, with one revision that was received by the convention on 21 September 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is home to at least 551 species of <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_China" title="List of mammals of China">mammals</a> (the third-highest such number in the world),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[158]</a></sup> 1,221 species of birds (eighth),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[159]</a></sup> 424 species of reptiles (seventh)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[160]</a></sup> and 333 species of amphibians (seventh).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[161]</a></sup> Wildlife in China shares habitat with, and bears acute pressure from, the world's largest population of humans. At least 840 <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China" title="List of endangered and protected species of China">animal species are threatened, vulnerable or in danger of local extinction</a> in China, due mainly to human activity such as habitat destruction, pollution and poaching for food, fur and ingredients for <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">traditional Chinese medicine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[162]</a></sup> Endangered wildlife is protected by law, and as of 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has over 2,349 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_China" title="Protected areas of China">nature reserves</a>, covering a total area of 149.95 million hectares, 15 percent of China's total land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[163]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (January 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Most wild animals have been eliminated from the core agricultural regions of east and central China, but they have fared better in the mountainous south and west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[165]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Baiji" title="Baiji">Baiji</a> was confirmed extinct on 12 December 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has over 32,000 species of vascular plants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[167]</a></sup> and is home to a variety of forest types. Cold <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coniferous" title="Coniferous">coniferous</a> forests predominate in the north of the country, supporting animal species such as <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a>, along with over 120 bird species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rough_guide_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-192">[168]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Understory" title="Understory">understory</a> of moist <a href="/wiki/Conifer" title="Conifer">conifer</a> forests may contain thickets of <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a>. In higher <a href="/wiki/Montane_ecosystems" title="Montane ecosystems">montane</a> stands of <a href="/wiki/Juniper" title="Juniper">juniper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxus" title="Taxus">yew</a>, the bamboo is replaced by <a href="/wiki/Rhododendron" title="Rhododendron">rhododendrons</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">Subtropical</a> forests, which are predominate in central and southern China, support a high density of plant species including numerous rare endemics. Tropical and seasonal <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a>, though confined to <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hainan_Island" title="Hainan Island">Hainan Island</a>, contain a quarter of all the animal and plant species found in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rough_guide_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-192">[168]</a></sup> China has over 10,000 recorded species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fungi" title="Fungi">fungi</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[169]</a></sup> and of them, nearly 6,000 are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Higher_fungi" title="Higher fungi">higher fungi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_China" title="Environment of China">Environment of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_China" title="Environmental issues in China">Environmental issues in China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_China" title="Renewable energy in China">Renewable energy in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_resources_of_China" title="Water resources of China">Water resources of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_China" title="Energy policy of China">Energy policy of China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_China" title="Climate change in China">Climate change in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1768" data-file-width="2847" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg/220px-ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg/330px-ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg/440px-ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam" title="Three Gorges Dam">Three Gorges Dam</a> is the largest hydroelectric dam in the world.</div></div></div>
<p>In the early 2000s, China has suffered from <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_China" title="Environmental issues in China">environmental deterioration and pollution</a> due to its rapid pace of industrialization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ma2002_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ma2002-195">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[172]</a></sup> While regulations such as the 1979 Environmental Protection Law are fairly stringent, they are poorly enforced, as they are frequently disregarded by local communities and government officials in favor of rapid economic development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[173]</a></sup> China is the country with the second highest death toll because of air pollution, after <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_India" title="Environmental issues in India">India</a>. There are approximately 1 million deaths caused by exposure to ambient air pollution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[175]</a></sup> Although China ranks as the highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions">CO<sub>2</sub> emitting</a> country in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[176]</a></sup> it only emits 8 tons of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions_per_capita" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions per capita">CO<sub>2</sub> per capita</a>, significantly lower than developed countries such as the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> (16.1), Australia (16.8) and South Korea (13.6).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-201">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, China has clamped down on pollution. In March 2014, CCP General Secretary Xi Jinping "declared war" on pollution during the opening of the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-largefines_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-largefines-202">[178]</a></sup> After extensive debate lasting nearly two years, the parliament approved a new environmental law in April. The new law empowers environmental enforcement agencies with great punitive power and large fines for offenders, defines areas which require extra protection, and gives independent environmental groups more ability to operate in the country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In 2020, Chinese Communist Party general secretary Xi Jinping announced that China aims to peak emissions before 2030 and go carbon-neutral by 2060 in accordance with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_climate_accord" title="Paris climate accord">Paris climate accord</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[179]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Climate_Action_Tracker" title="Climate Action Tracker">Climate Action Tracker</a>, if accomplished it would lower the expected rise in global temperature by 0.2 – 0.3 degrees – "the biggest single reduction ever estimated by the Climate Action Tracker".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[180]</a></sup> In September 2021 Xi Jinping announced that China will not build "coal-fired power projects abroad". The decision can be "pivotal" in reducing emissions. The <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a> did not include financing such projects already in the first half of 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country also had significant <a href="/wiki/Water_pollution" title="Water pollution">water pollution</a> problems: 8.2% of China's rivers had been polluted by industrial and agricultural waste in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[183]</a></sup> China had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.14/10, ranking it 53rd globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-208">[184]</a></sup> In 2020, a sweeping law was passed by the Chinese government to protect the ecology of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a>. The new laws include strengthening ecological protection rules for hydropower projects along the river, banning chemical plants within 1 kilometer of the river, relocating polluting industries, severely restricting sand mining as well as a complete fishing ban on all the natural waterways of the river, including all its major tributaries and lakes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is also the world's leading investor in <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialization" title="Renewable energy commercialization">its commercialization</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">$</a>52 billion invested in 2011 alone;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-By2010_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-By2010-210">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black2010_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-Black2010-211">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaLeadingEnergy_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaLeadingEnergy-212">[188]</a></sup> it is a major manufacturer of renewable energy technologies and invests heavily in local-scale renewable energy projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bradsher_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-bradsher-213">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[191]</a></sup> By 2015, over 24% of China's energy was derived from renewable sources, while most notably from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" title="Hydroelectric power">hydroelectric power</a>: a total installed capacity of 197 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gigawatt" title="Gigawatt">GW</a> makes China the <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity#World_hydroelectric_capacity" title="Hydroelectricity">largest hydroelectric power producer</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEA2015_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEA2015-217">[193]</a></sup> China also has the largest power capacity of <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_by_country" title="Solar power by country">installed solar photovoltaics system</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_by_country" title="Wind power by country">wind power system</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEA-PVPS-2016_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEA-PVPS-2016-218">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aweaQ4_2016_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-aweaQ4_2016-219">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_China" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by China">Greenhouse gas emissions by China</a> are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions">world's largest</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-201">[177]</a></sup> as is <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_China" title="Renewable energy in China">renewable energy in China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[196]</a></sup> Despite its emphasis on renewables, China remains deeply connected to global oil markets. Russia's single largest buyer, China takes in 20% of Russian oil exports, averaging 1.6 million barrels of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">crude oi</a>l per day in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_geography">Political geography</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_China" title="Borders of China">Borders of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coastline_of_China" title="Coastline of China">Coastline of China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China">Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="857" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/China_administrative.svg/200px-China_administrative.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/China_administrative.svg/300px-China_administrative.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/China_administrative.svg/400px-China_administrative.svg.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing the territorial claims of the PRC.</div></div></div>
<p>The People's Republic of China is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">second-largest</a> country in the world by land area after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[y]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[z]</a></sup> China's total area is generally stated as being approximately 9,600,000 km<sup>2</sup> (3,700,000 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[199]</a></sup> Specific area figures range from 9,572,900 km<sup>2</sup> (3,696,100 sq mi) according to the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[200]</a></sup> to 9,596,961 km<sup>2</sup> (3,705,407 sq mi) according to the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Demographic_Yearbook" title="UN Demographic Yearbook">UN Demographic Yearbook</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_Stat_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Stat-10">[5]</a></sup> and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-14">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_land_border_lengths" title="List of land border lengths">longest combined land border in the world</a>, measuring 22,117 km (13,743 mi) and its <a href="/wiki/Coastline_of_China" title="Coastline of China">coastline</a> covers approximately 14,500 km (9,000 mi) from the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Yalu_River" title="Yalu River">Yalu River</a> (Amnok River) to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin" title="Gulf of Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_14-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-14">[8]</a></sup> China <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_China" title="Borders of China">borders 14 nations</a> and covers the bulk of East Asia, bordering <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> in Southeast Asia; <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[aa]</a></sup> in South Asia; <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> in Central Asia; and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> in <a href="/wiki/Inner_Asia" title="Inner Asia">Inner Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Asia" title="Northeast Asia">Northeast Asia</a>. Additionally, China shares maritime boundaries with <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>. It is narrowly separated from <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> to the southwest and south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[201]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_China" title="Politics of China">Politics of China</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_Chinese_provincial_leaders" title="List of current Chinese provincial leaders">List of current Chinese provincial leaders</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Senate_House.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2430" data-file-width="4320" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/200px-China_Senate_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/300px-China_Senate_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/400px-China_Senate_House.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Great_Hall_of_the_People" title="Great Hall of the People">Great Hall of the People</a><br/>where the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a> convenes</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG/200px-Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG/300px-Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG/400px-Xinhuamen_Gate_of_Zhongnanhai_across_Changan_Street.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a>, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/State_Council_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="State Council of the People's Republic of China">Chinese government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">Chinese constitution</a> states that the People's Republic of China "is a socialist state governed by a people's democratic dictatorship that is led by the working class and based on an alliance of workers and peasants," and that the state institutions "shall practice the principle of democratic centralism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-229">[202]</a></sup> The PRC is one of the world's only <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist states</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ideology_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="Ideology of the Communist Party of China">governed by a communist party</a>. The Chinese government has been variously described as communist and socialist, but also as <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[203]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Corporatism" title="Corporatism">corporatist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[204]</a></sup> with heavy restrictions in many areas, most notably against <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_China" title="Internet censorship in China">free access to the Internet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">freedom of assembly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reproductive_rights" title="Reproductive rights">the right to have children</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NGO" title="NGO">free formation of social organizations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-232">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the Chinese Communist Party describes China as a "socialist consultative democracy",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[206]</a></sup> the country is commonly described as an authoritarian <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surveillance_state" title="Surveillance state">surveillance state</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[208]</a></sup> Its current political, ideological and economic system has been termed by its leaders as a "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_consultative_democracy" title="Socialist consultative democracy">consultative democracy</a>" "<a href="/wiki/People%27s_democratic_dictatorship" title="People's democratic dictatorship">people's democratic dictatorship</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a>" (which is <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a> adapted to Chinese circumstances) and the "<a href="/wiki/Socialist_market_economy" title="Socialist market economy">socialist market economy</a>" respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDPD_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-CDPD-236">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[210]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chinese_Communist_Party">Chinese Communist Party</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/United_Front_(China)" title="United Front (China)">United Front (China)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Generations_of_Chinese_leadership" title="Generations of Chinese leadership">Generations of Chinese leadership</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg/220px-18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg/330px-18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg/440px-18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> is the founding and ruling political party of the People's Republic of China.</div></div></div>
<p>Since 2018, the main body of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">Chinese constitution</a> declares that "the defining feature of <a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a> is the leadership of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2018-amendments-translated_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-2018-amendments-translated-238">[211]</a></sup> The 2018 amendments constitutionalized the <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a> status of China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2018-amendments-translated_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-2018-amendments-translated-238">[211]</a></sup> wherein the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP General Secretary</a> (<a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Leader of the Chinese Communist Party">party leader</a>) holds ultimate power and authority over state and government and serves as the informal <a href="/wiki/Paramount_leader" title="Paramount leader">Paramount leader</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[212]</a></sup> The current General Secretary is <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, who took office on 15 November 2012, and was re-elected on 25 October 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[213]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Elections in the People's Republic of China">electoral system</a> is pyramidal. Local People's Congresses are <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">directly elected</a>, and higher levels of People's Congresses up to the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a> (NPC) are <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">indirectly elected</a> by the People's Congress of the level immediately below.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-229">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_China" title="List of political parties in China">Another eight political parties</a>, have representatives in the NPC and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Political_Consultative_Conference" title="Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference">Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference</a> (CPPCC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[214]</a></sup> China supports the Leninist principle of "<a href="/wiki/Democratic_centralism" title="Democratic centralism">democratic centralism</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_229-2"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-229">[202]</a></sup> but critics describe the elected National People's Congress as a "<a href="/wiki/Rubber_stamp_(politics)" title="Rubber stamp (politics)">rubber stamp</a>" body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since both the CCP and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> (PLA) promote according to seniority, it is possible to discern distinct <a href="/wiki/Generations_of_Chinese_leadership" title="Generations of Chinese leadership">generations of Chinese leadership</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-243">[216]</a></sup> In official discourse, each group of leadership is identified with a distinct extension of the ideology of the party. Historians have studied various periods in the development of the government of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a> by reference to these "generations".
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_China" title="Government of China">Government of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_leaders_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of national leaders of the People's Republic of China">List of national leaders of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:369px;max-width:369px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:117px;max-width:117px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="739" data-file-width="553" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg/115px-Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg/173px-Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg/230px-Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg 2x" width="115"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP General Secretary</a>
and <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">President</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:122px;max-width:122px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dmitry_Medvedev_and_Li_Keqiang_20191101_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="367" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Dmitry_Medvedev_and_Li_Keqiang_20191101_%28cropped%29.jpg/180px-Dmitry_Medvedev_and_Li_Keqiang_20191101_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Dmitry_Medvedev_and_Li_Keqiang_20191101_%28cropped%29.jpg/240px-Dmitry_Medvedev_and_Li_Keqiang_20191101_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premier</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:124px;max-width:124px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="475" data-file-width="380" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg/122px-2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg/183px-2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg/244px-2022_Li_Zhanshu.jpg 2x" width="122"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Li_Zhanshu" title="Li Zhanshu">Li Zhanshu</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Standing_Committee_of_the_National_People%27s_Congress" title="Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress">Congress Chairman</a></small></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>China is a <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a> led by the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP). The National People's Congress in 2018 altered the country's constitution to remove the two-term limit on holding the Presidency of China, permitting the current leader, <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, to remain president of China (and general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party) for an unlimited time, earning criticism for creating <a href="/wiki/Dictator" title="Dictator">dictatorial</a> governance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BaturoElgie2019_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-BaturoElgie2019-244">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kroenig2020_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kroenig2020-245">[218]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">president</a> is the titular <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, elected by the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">premier</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, presiding over the <a href="/wiki/State_Council_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="State Council of the People's Republic of China">State Council</a> composed of four vice premiers and the heads of ministries and commissions. The incumbent president is <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, who is also the General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party and the <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission_(China)" title="Chairman of the Central Military Commission (China)">chairman of the Central Military Commission</a>, making him China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramount_leader_(China)" title="Paramount leader (China)">paramount leader</a>. The incumbent premier is <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, who is also a senior member of the CCP <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Politburo_Standing_Committee" title="Politburo Standing Committee">Politburo Standing Committee</a>, China's <i>de facto</i> top decision-making body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XiJinpingLiKeqiang_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-XiJinpingLiKeqiang-247">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Political concerns in China include the growing gap between rich and poor and government corruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[221]</a></sup> Nonetheless, the level of public support for the government and its management of the nation is high, with 80–95% of Chinese citizens expressing satisfaction with the central government, according to a 2011 survey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[222]</a></sup> A 2020 survey from the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Institutes_of_Health_Research" title="Canadian Institutes of Health Research">Canadian Institutes of Health Research</a> also had most Chinese expressing satisfaction with the government on information dissemination and delivery of daily necessities during the COVID-19 pandemic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_China" title="Administrative divisions of China">Administrative divisions of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Hong_Kong" title="Districts of Hong Kong">Districts of Hong Kong</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_and_parishes_of_Macau" title="Municipalities and parishes of Macau">Municipalities and parishes of Macau</a></div>
<p>The People's Republic of China is officially divided into 23 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a>,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> five <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a> (each with a designated minority group), and four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct-controlled_municipality_of_China" title="Direct-controlled municipality of China">municipalities</a>—collectively referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>"—as well as the <a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">special administrative regions</a> (SARs) of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>. Geographically, all 31 provincial divisions of mainland China can be grouped into six regions: <a href="/wiki/North_China" title="North China">North China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_China" title="Northeast China">Northeast China</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_China" title="East China">East China</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Central_China" title="South Central China">South Central China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwest_China" title="Southwest China">Southwest China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northwest_China" title="Northwest China">Northwest China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown2013_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brown2013-252">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>China considers <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to be <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China">its 23rd province</a>,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> although Taiwan is governed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> (ROC), which rejects the PRC's claim. Conversely, the ROC constitution claims sovereignty over all divisions governed by the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[226]</a></sup>
</p>

<li><a href="/wiki/Gansu" title="Gansu">Gansu</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">甘肃省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">广东省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guizhou" title="Guizhou">Guizhou</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">贵州省</span></span>)</li></ul>
</td>
<td>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">海南省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hebei" title="Hebei">Hebei</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">河北省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Heilongjiang" title="Heilongjiang">Heilongjiang</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">黑龙江省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Henan" title="Henan">Henan</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">河南省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hubei" title="Hubei">Hubei</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">湖北省</span></span>)</li></ul>
</td>

<li><a href="/wiki/Jilin" title="Jilin">Jilin</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">吉林省</span></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Liaoning" title="Liaoning">Liaoning</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">辽宁省</span></span>)</li></ul>

</td></tr>

<li><a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> / <i>Aomen</i> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">澳门特别行政区</span></span>)</li></ul>
</td></tr></tbody></table><div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_China" title="Foreign relations of China">Foreign relations of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/310px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/465px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/620px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Diplomatic relations of China</div></div></div>
<p>The PRC has <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_China" title="List of diplomatic missions in China">diplomatic relations</a> with 175 countries and maintains <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of diplomatic missions of the People's Republic of China">embassies in 162</a>.
