In 2019, China had the largest diplomatic network in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-255">[228]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Legitimacy_(political)" title="Legitimacy (political)">legitimacy</a> is disputed by the Republic of China and a few other countries; it is thus the largest and most populous <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">state with limited recognition</a>, with a population of more than 1.4 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[229]</a></sup> In 1971, the PRC replaced the Republic of China as the sole representative of China in the United Nations and as one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_r_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_r-257">[230]</a></sup> China was also a former member and leader of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and still considers itself an advocate for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009-258">[231]</a></sup> Along with Brazil, Russia, India and South Africa, China is a member of the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> group of emerging major economies and hosted the group's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2011_BRICS_summit" title="2011 BRICS summit">third official summit</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sanya" title="Sanya">Sanya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> in April 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the <a href="/wiki/One_China" title="One China">One-China principle</a>, Beijing has made it a precondition to establishing diplomatic relations that the other country acknowledges its claim to Taiwan and severs official ties with the government of the Republic of China.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Chinese officials have protested on numerous occasions when foreign countries have made diplomatic overtures to Taiwan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[233]</a></sup> especially in the matter of armament sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of current Chinese foreign policy is reportedly based on Premier <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Five_Principles_of_Peaceful_Coexistence" title="Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence">Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence</a>, and is also driven by the concept of "harmony without uniformity", which encourages diplomatic relations between states despite ideological differences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keith_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-Keith-262">[235]</a></sup> This policy may have led China to support states that are <a href="/wiki/Rogue_state" title="Rogue state">regarded as dangerous</a> or repressive by Western nations, such as <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Zimbabwe_relations" title="China–Zimbabwe relations">Zimbabwe</a>, <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93North_Korea_relations" title="China–North Korea relations">North Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Iran_relations" title="China–Iran relations">Iran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[236]</a></sup> China has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino-Russian_relations_since_1991" title="Sino-Russian relations since 1991">close economic and military relationship</a> with Russia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[237]</a></sup> and the two states often vote in unison in the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[240]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_relations">Trade relations</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3372" data-file-width="4894" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/230px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/345px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/460px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg 2x" width="230"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>On 21 May 2014, China and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> signed a $400 billion <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Russia" title="Natural gas in Russia">gas deal</a>. Currently, Russia is supplying <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">natural gas</a> to China.</div></div></div>
<p>China became the world's largest trading nation in 2013 as measured by the sum of imports and exports, as well as the world's largest commodity importer. comprising roughly 45% of maritime's <a href="/wiki/Shipping_markets" title="Shipping markets">dry-bulk market</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[242]</a></sup>
By 2016, China was the largest trading partner of 124 other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[243]</a></sup> China is the largest trading partner for the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> nations, with a total trade value of $345.8 billion in 2015 accounting for 15.2% of ASEAN's total trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[244]</a></sup> ASEAN is also China's largest trading partner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[245]</a></sup> In 2020, China became the largest trading partner of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> for goods, with the total value of goods trade reaching nearly $700 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-qz_EU_trade_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-qz_EU_trade-273">[246]</a></sup> China, along with ASEAN, Japan, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand, is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership" title="Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership">Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership</a>, the world's largest free-trade area covering 30% of the world's population and economic output.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[247]</a></sup> China became a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO) in 2001. In 2004, it proposed an entirely new <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS) framework as a forum for regional security issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_s_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_s-275">[248]</a></sup> The EAS, which includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN_Plus_Three" title="ASEAN Plus Three">ASEAN Plus Three</a>, India, Australia and New Zealand, held its inaugural summit in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has had a long and complex trade relationship with the United States. In 2000, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> approved "permanent normal trade relations" (PNTR) with China, allowing Chinese exports in at the same low tariffs as goods from most other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[250]</a></sup> China has a significant <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_surplus" title="Trade surplus">trade surplus</a> with the United States, its most important export market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[251]</a></sup> Economists have argued that the <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">renminbi</a> is undervalued, due to <a href="/wiki/Currency_intervention" title="Currency intervention">currency intervention</a> from the Chinese government, giving China an unfair trade advantage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[252]</a></sup> In August 2019, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">United States Department of the Treasury</a> designated China as a "<a href="/wiki/Currency_manipulator" title="Currency manipulator">currency manipulator</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[253]</a></sup> later reversing the decision in January 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the turn of the century, China has followed a policy of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involvement_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China_in_Africa" title="Involvement of the People's Republic of China in Africa">engaging with African nations</a> for trade and bilateral co-operation;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[257]</a></sup> in 2019, Sino-African trade totalled $208 billion, having grown 20 times over two decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[258]</a></sup> According to Madison Condon "China finances more infrastructure projects in Africa than the World Bank and provides billions of dollars in low-interest loans to the continent's emerging economies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[259]</a></sup> China maintains extensive and highly diversified trade links with the European Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-qz_EU_trade_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-qz_EU_trade-273">[246]</a></sup> China has furthermore strengthened its trade ties with major South American economies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[260]</a></sup> and is the largest trading partner of Brazil, Chile, Peru, Uruguay, Argentina, and several others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a> has expanded significantly over the last six years and, as of April 2020, includes 138 countries and 30 international organizations. In addition to intensifying foreign policy relations, the focus here is particularly on building efficient transport routes. The focus is particularly on the <a href="/wiki/21st_Century_Maritime_Silk_Road" title="21st Century Maritime Silk Road">maritime Silk Road</a> with its connections to East Africa and Europe and there are Chinese investments or related declarations of intent at numerous ports such as <a href="/wiki/Gwadar" title="Gwadar">Gwadar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuantan" title="Kuantan">Kuantan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hambantota" title="Hambantota">Hambantota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piraeus" title="Piraeus">Piraeus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a>. However many of these loans made under the Belt and Road program are unsustainable and China has faced a number of calls for <a href="/wiki/Debt_relief" title="Debt relief">debt relief</a> from debtor nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[263]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Territorial_disputes">Territorial disputes</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Territorial_disputes_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Territorial disputes of the People's Republic of China">Territorial disputes of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of wars involving the People's Republic of China">List of wars involving the People's Republic of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a></div>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Taiwan">Taiwan</span></h5>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="857" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/200px-China_administrative.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/300px-China_administrative.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/400px-China_administrative.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map depicting territorial disputes between the PRC and neighboring states. For a larger map, <a href="/wiki/Template:PRC_provinces_big_imagemap" title="Template:PRC provinces big imagemap">see here</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ever since its establishment after the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, the PRC has claimed <a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">the territories</a> governed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> (ROC), a separate political entity today commonly known as Taiwan, as a part of its territory. It regards the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Island_of_Taiwan" title="Island of Taiwan">island of Taiwan</a> as its <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China">Taiwan Province</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kinmen" title="Kinmen">Kinmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Matsu_Islands" title="Matsu Islands">Matsu</a> as a part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fujian_Province" title="Fujian Province">Fujian Province</a> and islands the ROC controls in the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> as a part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hainan_Province" title="Hainan Province">Hainan Province</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guangdong_Province" title="Guangdong Province">Guangdong Province</a>. These claims are controversial because of the complicated <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a>, with the PRC treating the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One-China_Principle" title="One-China Principle">One-China Principle</a> as one of its most important diplomatic principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[264]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (November 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Land_border_disputes">Land border disputes</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute" title="Sino-Indian border dispute">Sino-Indian border dispute</a></div>
<p>China has resolved its land borders with 12 out of 14 neighboring countries, having pursued substantial compromises in most of them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[267]</a></sup> As of 2022, China currently has a disputed land border with <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Maritime_border_disputes">Maritime border disputes</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Territorial_disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea" title="Territorial disputes in the South China Sea">Territorial disputes in the South China Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_Islands_dispute" title="Senkaku Islands dispute">Senkaku Islands dispute</a></div>
<p>China is additionally involved in maritime disputes with multiple countries over the ownership of several small islands in the East and South China Seas, such as <a href="/wiki/Socotra_Rock" title="Socotra Rock">Socotra Rock</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_Islands_dispute" title="Senkaku Islands dispute">Senkaku Islands</a> and the entirety of <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea_Islands" title="South China Sea Islands">South China Sea Islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[269]</a></sup> along with the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea_EEZ_disputes" title="East China Sea EEZ disputes">EEZ disputes over East China Sea</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sociopolitical_issues_and_human_rights">Sociopolitical issues and human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">Human rights in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hukou" title="Hukou">Hukou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_welfare_in_China" title="Social welfare in China">Social welfare in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_China" title="Elections in China">Elections in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">Censorship in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_genocide" title="Uyghur genocide">Uyghur genocide</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/220px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/330px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/440px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>March in memory of Chinese <a href="/wiki/2010_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2010 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> laureate <a href="/wiki/Liu_Xiaobo" title="Liu Xiaobo">Liu Xiaobo</a> who died of organ failure while in government custody in 2017</div></div></div>
<p>China uses a massive espionage network of cameras, facial recognition software, sensors, and surveillance of personal technology as a means of social control of persons living in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[270]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_democracy_movement" title="Chinese democracy movement">Chinese democracy movement</a>, social activists, and some members of the Chinese Communist Party believe in the need for social and political reform. While economic and social controls have been significantly relaxed in China since the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Political_freedom" title="Political freedom">political freedom</a> is still tightly restricted. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">Constitution of the People's Republic of China</a> states that the "fundamental rights" of citizens include <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Right_to_a_fair_trial" title="Right to a fair trial">right to a fair trial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Property" title="Property">property rights</a>. However, in practice, these provisions do not afford significant protection against criminal prosecution by the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-298">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-299">[272]</a></sup> Although some criticisms of government policies and the ruling <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Communist Party</a> are tolerated, censorship of political speech and information, most notably on the Internet,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnonymousNoMore_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-AnonymousNoMore-301">[274]</a></sup> are routinely used to prevent collective action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of foreign governments, foreign press agencies, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NGO" title="NGO">NGOs</a> have criticized <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">China's human rights record</a>, alleging widespread <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights">civil rights</a> violations such as detention without trial, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced_abortions" title="Forced abortions">forced abortions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[276]</a></sup> forced confessions, <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a>, restrictions of fundamental rights,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-232">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-304">[277]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Capital punishment in the People's Republic of China">excessive use of the death penalty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wp_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-wp-305">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[279]</a></sup> The government suppresses popular protests and demonstrations that it considers a potential threat to "social stability", as was the case with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">Tiananmen Square protests of 1989</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xinjiang_Internment_Map,_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1267" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg/220px-Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg/330px-Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg/440px-Xinjiang_Internment_Map%2C_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Xinjiang_Internment_Map,_US-Aus_Gov_Assessment.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Western governments accused China of committing <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_genocide" title="Uyghur genocide">genocide against Uyghurs</a> and detaining more than one million <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghurs</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> minorities in camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[281]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>China is regularly accused of large-scale repression and human rights abuses in <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Tibet" title="Human rights in Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_genocide" title="Uyghur genocide">Xinjiang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[284]</a></sup> including violent police crackdowns and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_suppression" title="Religious suppression">religious suppression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[286]</a></sup> In Xinjiang, At least one million <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghurs</a> and other ethnic and religion minorities have been detained in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xinjiang_re-education_camps" title="Xinjiang re-education camps">mass detention camps</a>, officially termed "Vocational Education and Training Centers", aimed at changing the political thinking of detainees, their identities, and their religious beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:13_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-:13-159">[135]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">U.S. Department of State</a>, actions including political <a href="/wiki/Indoctrination" title="Indoctrination">indoctrination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Physical_abuse" title="Physical abuse">physical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Psychological_abuse" title="Psychological abuse">psychological</a> abuse, <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_sterilization" title="Compulsory sterilization">forced sterilization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abuse" title="Sexual abuse">sexual abuse</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unfree_labour" title="Unfree labour">forced labor</a> are common in these facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[287]</a></sup> The state has also sought to control offshore reporting of tensions in Xinjiang, intimidating foreign-based reporters by detaining their family members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[288]</a></sup> According to a 2020 report, China's treatment of Uyghurs meets the UN definition of genocide,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[289]</a></sup> and several groups called for a UN investigation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[290]</a></sup> On 19 January 2021, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State" title="United States Secretary of State">United States Secretary of State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pompeo" title="Mike Pompeo">Mike Pompeo</a>, announced that the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">United States Department of State</a> had determined that "genocide and crimes against humanity" had been perpetrated by China against the Uyghurs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsj._U.S._says_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsj._U.S._says-318">[291]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_(48108594957).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2922" data-file-width="3897" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg/220px-Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg/330px-Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg/440px-Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_%2848108594957%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hong_Kong_anti-extradition_bill_protest_(48108594957).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Hong_Kong_protests" title="2019–20 Hong Kong protests">2019–20 Hong Kong protests</a></div></div></div>
<p>Global studies from <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> in 2014 and 2017 ranked the Chinese government's restrictions on religion as among the highest in the world, despite low to moderate rankings for religious-related social hostilities in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[293]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Global_Slavery_Index" title="Global Slavery Index">Global Slavery Index</a> estimated that in 2016 more than 3.8 million people were living in "conditions of modern <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_China" title="Slavery in China">slavery</a>", or 0.25% of the population, including victims of human trafficking, forced labor, forced marriage, child labor, and state-imposed forced labor. The state-imposed forced system was formally abolished in 2013, but it is not clear to which extent its various practices have stopped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[294]</a></sup> The Chinese penal system includes labor prison factories, detention centers, and re-education camps, collectively known as <i><a href="/wiki/Laogai" title="Laogai">laogai</a></i> ("reform through labor"). The Laogai Research Foundation in the United States estimated that there were over a thousand slave labor prisons and camps in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, a study called for the mass retraction of more than 400 scientific papers on <a href="/wiki/Organ_transplantation_in_China" title="Organ transplantation in China">organ transplantation</a>, because of fears the organs were obtained unethically from Chinese prisoners. While the government says 10,000 transplants occur each year, a report by the <a href="/wiki/Falun_Gong" title="Falun Gong">Falun Gong</a>-linked IETAC alleged that between 60,000 and 100,000 organs are transplanted each year and claimed that this gap was being made up by executed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_conscience" title="Prisoners of conscience">prisoners of conscience</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_China" title="Paramilitary forces of China">Paramilitary forces of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1334" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/220px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/330px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/440px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-20" title="Chengdu J-20">Chengdu J-20</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fifth-generation_jet_fighter" title="Fifth-generation jet fighter">5th generation</a> stealth fighter</div></div></div>
<p>With nearly 2.2 million active troops, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> (PLA) is the largest standing military force in the world, commanded by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)" title="Central Military Commission (People's Republic of China)">Central Military Commission</a> (CMC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdep_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdep-324">[297]</a></sup> China has the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Military_reserve_force" title="Military reserve force">military reserve force</a>, only behind <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[298]</a></sup> The PLA is considered one of the world's most powerful militaries, and has rapidly modernized in the recent decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[299]</a></sup> The PLA consists of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Ground_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Ground Force">Ground Force</a> (PLAGF), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Navy" title="People's Liberation Army Navy">Navy</a> (PLAN), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">Air Force</a> (PLAAF), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Rocket_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Rocket Force">Rocket Force</a> (PLARF) and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Strategic_Support_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Strategic Support Force">Strategic Support Force</a> (PLASSF). According to the Chinese government, military budget for 2022 totalled US$230 billion (1.45 trillion Yuan), constituting the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">world's second-largest military budget</a>, although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP" title="List of countries by military expenditure share of GDP">military expenditures-GDP ratio</a> with 1.3% of GDP is below world average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI2014_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI2014-328">[301]</a></sup> However, many authorities – including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SIPRI" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a> and the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Secretary_of_Defense" title="Office of the Secretary of Defense">Office of the Secretary of Defense</a> claim that China hides its real level of military spending, which is allegedly much higher than the official budget.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI2014_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI2014-328">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeq_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeq-329">[302]</a></sup> The PLA additionally holds the world's <a href="/wiki/China_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="China and weapons of mass destruction">third-largest stockpile of nuclear weapons</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[305]</a></sup> and the world's second-largest navy by tonnage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_China" title="Economy of China">Economy of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_China" title="Agriculture in China">Agriculture in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP">List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="737" data-file-width="1563" decoding="async" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/220px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/330px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/440px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China and other major developing economies by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita at purchasing-power parity</a>, 1990–2013. The rapid economic growth of China (blue) is readily apparent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[307]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/290px-China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/435px-China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/580px-China_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Chinese exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Since 2010, China has had <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">the world's second-largest economy</a> in terms of nominal GDP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[308]</a></sup> totaling approximately US$18 trillion (114.3 trillion Yuan) as of 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:14_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-:14-336">[309]</a></sup> In terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (GDP PPP), China's economy has been the largest in the world since 2014, according to the World Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[310]</a></sup> China is also the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing</a> major economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[311]</a></sup> According to the World Bank, China's GDP grew from $150 billion in 1978 to $14.28 trillion by 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[312]</a></sup> China's economic growth has been consistently above 6 percent since the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms in 1978</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[313]</a></sup> China is also the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">largest exporter</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">second-largest importer</a> of goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaBiggestTrader_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaBiggestTrader-341">[314]</a></sup> Between 2010 and 2019, China's contribution to global GDP growth has been 25% to 39%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[316]</a></sup> It is the largest engine of global growth for the world economy, accounting for 25–30% global total expansion since the financial crisis of 2008–2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bergsten_2022_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bergsten_2022-344">[317]</a></sup> As of 2021, China accounts for 18% of the world economy by GDP nominal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:14_336-1"><a href="#cite_note-:14-336">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>China had one of the <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_before_1912" title="Economic history of China before 1912">largest economies in the world</a> for most of the <a href="/wiki/Pax_Sinica" title="Pax Sinica">past two thousand years</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[318]</a></sup> during which it has seen cycles of prosperity and decline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[320]</a></sup> Since economic reforms began in 1978, China has developed into a highly diversified economy and one of the most consequential players in international trade. Major sectors of competitive strength include manufacturing, retail, mining, steel, textiles, automobiles, energy generation, green energy, banking, electronics, telecommunications, real estate, e-commerce, and tourism. China has three out of the ten largest stock exchanges in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[321]</a></sup>—<a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Stock_Exchange" title="Shanghai Stock Exchange">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Stock_Exchange" title="Hong Kong Stock Exchange">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen_Stock_Exchange" title="Shenzhen Stock Exchange">Shenzhen</a>—that together have a market capitalization of over $15.9 trillion, as of October 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[322]</a></sup> China has four (<a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>) out of the world's top ten most competitive financial centers, which is more than any country in the 2020 <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">Global Financial Centres Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GFCI2_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-GFCI2-350">[323]</a></sup> By 2035, China's four cities (Shanghai, Beijing, <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> and Shenzhen) are projected to be among the global top ten largest cities by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> according to a report by Oxford Economics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has been the world's No. 1 manufacturer since 2010, after overtaking the US, which had been No. 1 for the previous hundred years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[326]</a></sup> China has also been No. 2 in high-tech manufacturing since 2012, according to US <a href="/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">National Science Foundation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[327]</a></sup> China is the second largest retail market in the world, next to the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[328]</a></sup> China leads the world in e-commerce, accounting for 40% of the global market share in 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[329]</a></sup> and more than 50% of the global market share in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[330]</a></sup> China is the world's leader in electric vehicles, manufacturing and buying half of all the plug-in electric cars (BEV and PHEV) in the world in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[331]</a></sup> China is also the leading producer of batteries for electric vehicles as well as several key raw materials for batteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[332]</a></sup> China had 174 GW of installed solar capacity by the end of 2018, which amounts to more than 40% of the global solar capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>Foreign and some Chinese sources have claimed that official Chinese government statistics overstate China's economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Plekhanov2017_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-Plekhanov2017-363">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChenChenHsiehSong2019_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChenChenHsiehSong2019-364">[337]</a></sup> However, several Western academics and institutions have stated that China's economic growth is higher than indicated by official figures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:12_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-:12-365">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:52_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-:52-366">[339]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[340]</a></sup> Others, such as the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>, state that while there's evidence China's GDP data is "smoothed", they believe that China's nominal and real GDP data are broadly accurate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has a large <a href="/wiki/Informal_economy_of_China" title="Informal economy of China">informal economy</a>, which arose as a result of the country's economic opening. The informal economy is a source of employment and income for workers, but it is unrecognized and suffers from lower productivity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wealth_in_China">Wealth in China</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg/220px-Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg/330px-Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg/440px-Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shanghai_skyscrapers_5166285.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shanghai_World_Financial_Center" title="Shanghai World Financial Center">Shanghai World Financial Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jin_Mao_Tower" title="Jin Mao Tower">Jin Mao Tower</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Tower" title="Shanghai Tower">Shanghai Tower, Lujiazui</a></div></div></div>
<p>As of 2020, China was second in the world, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a>, in total number of billionaires and total number of millionaires, with 698 Chinese billionaires and 4.4 million millionaires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[344]</a></sup> In 2019, China overtook the US as the home to the highest number of people who have a net personal wealth of at least $110,000, according to the global wealth report by <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[346]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Hurun" title="Hurun">Hurun</a> Global Rich List 2020, China is home to five of the world's top ten cities (<a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> in the 1st, 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 10th spots, respectively) by the highest number of billionaires, which is more than any other country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:17_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-:17-374">[347]</a></sup> China had 85 female billionaires as of January 2021, two-thirds of the global total, and minted 24 new female billionaires in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, it ranks behind over 60 countries (out of around 180) in per capita economic output, making it an upper-middle income country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[349]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a>, on a <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a> basis among countries with a large population of over 100 million as of 2021, China ranked 3rd by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">GDP per capita (nominal)</a> and 5th by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita (PPP)</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[350]</a></sup> Additionally, its development is highly uneven. Its major cities and coastal areas are far more prosperous compared to rural and interior regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[351]</a></sup> China brought more people out of extreme poverty than any other country in history<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[352]</a></sup>—between 1978 and 2018, China reduced extreme poverty by 800 million. China reduced the extreme poverty rate—per international standard, it refers to an income of less than $1.90/day—from 88% in 1981 to 1.85% by 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-380">[353]</a></sup> According to the World Bank, the number of Chinese in extreme poverty fell from 756 million to 25 million between 1990 and 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[354]</a></sup> The portion of people in China living below the international poverty line of $1.90 per day (2011 <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>) fell to 0.3% in 2018 from 66.3% in 1990. Using the lower-middle income poverty line of $3.20 per day, the portion fell to 2.9% in 2018 from 90.0% in 1990. Using the upper-middle income poverty line of $5.50 per day, the portion fell to 17.0% from 98.3% in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[355]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_growth">Economic growth</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For Economic history of China, see <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_before_1912" title="Economic history of China before 1912">Economic history of China before 1912</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Economic history of China (1912–1949)">Economic history of China (1912–1949)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_(1949%E2%80%93present)" title="Economic history of China (1949–present)">Economic history of China (1949–present)</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prc1952-2005gdp.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="675" data-file-width="1161" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Prc1952-2005gdp.gif/220px-Prc1952-2005gdp.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Prc1952-2005gdp.gif/330px-Prc1952-2005gdp.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Prc1952-2005gdp.gif/440px-Prc1952-2005gdp.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prc1952-2005gdp.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China's nominal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_Domestic_Product" title="Gross Domestic Product">GDP</a> trend from 1952 to 2015</div></div></div>
<p>From its founding in 1949 until late 1978, the People's Republic of China was a Soviet-style centrally <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>. Following Mao's death in 1976 and the consequent end of the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> and the new Chinese leadership began to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_reform_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Economic reform in the People's Republic of China">reform the economy</a> and move towards a more market-oriented <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> under one-party rule. <a href="/wiki/Collective_farming" title="Collective farming">Agricultural collectivization</a> was dismantled and farmlands privatized, while foreign trade became a major new focus, leading to the creation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Economic_Zone" title="Special Economic Zone">Special Economic Zones</a> (SEZs). Inefficient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government-owned_corporation" title="Government-owned corporation">state-owned enterprises</a> (SOEs) were restructured and unprofitable ones were closed outright, resulting in massive job losses.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Modern-day China is mainly characterized as having a market economy based on private property ownership,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.eastday_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-english.eastday-383">[356]</a></sup> and is one of the leading examples of <a href="/wiki/State_capitalism" title="State capitalism">state capitalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[358]</a></sup> The state still dominates in strategic "pillar" sectors such as energy production and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">heavy industries</a>, but private enterprise has expanded enormously, with around 30 million private businesses recorded in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abf_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abf-386">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005-387">[360]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (November 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2005a_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2005a-388">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abg_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abg-389">[362]</a></sup> In 2018, private enterprises in China accounted for 60% of GDP, 80% of urban employment and 90% of new jobs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 2010s, China's economic growth rate began to slow amid domestic credit troubles, weakening international demand for Chinese exports and fragility in the global economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[366]</a></sup> China's GDP was slightly larger than Germany's in 2007; however, by 2017, China's $12.2 trillion-economy became larger than those of Germany, UK, France and Italy combined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[367]</a></sup> In 2018, the IMF reiterated its forecast that China will overtake the US in terms of nominal GDP by 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[368]</a></sup> Economists also expect China's middle class to expand to 600 million people by 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[369]</a></sup>
</p><p>China was the only major economy in the world to grow in 2020, recording a 2.3% growth due to its success in containing the coronavirus within its borders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[370]</a></sup> However, by April 2022, China's debt-to-GDP ratio had grown to 270%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="China_in_the_global_economy">China in the global economy</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: left; margin-right: 10px;">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[372]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Year
</th>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Share
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1980</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2.32%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1990</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">4.11%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2000
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">7.40%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2010
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">13.89%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">2018</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">18.72%
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>China is a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> and is the world's largest trading power, with a total international trade value of US$4.62 trillion in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[373]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Foreign exchange reserves of the People's Republic of China">Its foreign exchange reserves</a> reached US$3.1 trillion as of 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[374]</a></sup> making its reserves by far the world's largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009b_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009b-402">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[376]</a></sup> In 2012, China was the world's largest recipient of inward <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), attracting $253 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDI_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-404">[377]</a></sup> In 2014, China's foreign exchange remittances were $US64 billion making it the second largest recipient of remittances in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[378]</a></sup> China also invests abroad, with a total outward FDI of $62.4 billion in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDI_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-404">[377]</a></sup> and a number of major takeovers of foreign firms by Chinese companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[379]</a></sup> China is a major owner of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_public_debt" title="US public debt">US public debt</a>, holding trillions of dollars worth of U.S. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treasury_bond" title="Treasury bond">Treasury bonds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abe_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abe-407">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hornby2009_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hornby2009-408">[381]</a></sup> China's undervalued exchange rate has caused friction with other major economies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CurrencyManipulator_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-409">[382]</a></sup> and it has also been widely criticized for manufacturing large quantities of <a href="/wiki/Counterfeit" title="Counterfeit">counterfeit</a> goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[384]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="floatright">
<table border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="float:right;">
<tbody><tr>
<td><div class="timeline-wrapper"><map name="timeline_lsvdi6c5mcynq8zb7m8tuhef6bwxq4e"></map><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/lsvdi6c5mcynq8zb7m8tuhef6bwxq4e.png" usemap="#timeline_lsvdi6c5mcynq8zb7m8tuhef6bwxq4e"/></div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center; font-size:100%;">Largest economies by nominal GDP in 2018<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[385]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</div>
<p>Following the 2007–08 financial crisis, Chinese authorities sought to actively wean off of its dependence on the U.S. dollar as a result of perceived weaknesses of the international monetary system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[386]</a></sup> To achieve those ends, China took a series of actions to further the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internationalization_of_the_Renminbi" title="Internationalization of the Renminbi">internationalization of the Renminbi</a>. In 2008, China established <a href="/wiki/Dim_sum_bond" title="Dim sum bond">dim sum bond</a> market and expanded the Cross-Border Trade RMB Settlement Pilot Project, which helps establish pools of offshore RMB liquidity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[388]</a></sup> This was followed with bilateral agreements to settle trades directly in renminbi with Russia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[389]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[390]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[391]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-massg_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-massg-419">[392]</a></sup> the United Kingdom,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[393]</a></sup> and Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[394]</a></sup> As a result of the rapid internationalization of the renminbi, it became the eighth-most-traded currency in the world, an emerging international <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igtop10_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-igtop10-422">[395]</a></sup> and a component of the IMF's <a href="/wiki/Special_drawing_rights" title="Special drawing rights">special drawing rights</a>; however, partly due to capital controls that make the renminbi fall short of being a fully convertible currency, it remains far behind the Euro, Dollar and Japanese Yen in international trade volumes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Class_and_income_inequality">Class and income inequality</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_China" title="Income inequality in China">Income inequality in China</a></div>
<p>China has had the world's largest middle class population since 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[397]</a></sup> and the middle class grew to a size of 400 million by 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[398]</a></sup> In 2020, a study by the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a> forecast that China's middle-class will reach 1.2 billion by 2027 (almost 4 times the entire U.S. population today), making up one fourth of the world total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1978 to 2018, the average standard of living multiplied by a factor of twenty-six.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bergsten_2022_344-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bergsten_2022-344">[317]</a></sup> Wages in China have grown a lot in the last 40 years—real (inflation-adjusted) wages grew seven-fold from 1978 to 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[400]</a></sup> Per capita incomes have risen significantly – when the PRC was founded in 1949, per capita income in China was one fifth of the world average; per capita incomes now equal the world average itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bergsten_2022_344-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bergsten_2022-344">[317]</a></sup> By 2018, median wages in Chinese cities such as Shanghai were about the same as or higher than the wages in Eastern European countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[401]</a></sup> China has the world's highest number of billionaires, with nearly 878 as of October 2020, increasing at the rate of roughly five per week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-429">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-430">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[404]</a></sup> China has a high level of economic inequality,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[405]</a></sup> which has increased in the past few decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[406]</a></sup> In 2018 China's <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a> was 0.467, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GINI_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-GINI-20">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_China" title="Science and technology in China">Science and technology in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_space_program" title="Chinese space program">Chinese space program</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_discoveries" title="List of Chinese discoveries">List of Chinese discoveries</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions" title="List of Chinese inventions">List of Chinese inventions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_China" title="History of science and technology in China">History of science and technology in China</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical">Historical</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="864" data-file-width="1194" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG/220px-Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG/330px-Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG/440px-Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Gunpowder_Formula.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Earliest known written formula for gunpowder, from the <i><a href="/wiki/Wujing_Zongyao" title="Wujing Zongyao">Wujing Zongyao</a></i> of 1044 CE</div></div></div>
<p>China was a world leader in science and technology until the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[407]</a></sup> Ancient <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_discoveries" title="List of Chinese discoveries">Chinese discoveries</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions" title="List of Chinese inventions">inventions</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_typography_in_East_Asia" title="History of typography in East Asia">printing</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Four_Great_Inventions" title="Four Great Inventions">Four Great Inventions</a>), became widespread across East Asia, the Middle East and later Europe. Chinese mathematicians were the first to use <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Negative_numbers#History" title="Negative numbers">negative numbers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[408]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[409]</a></sup> By the 17th century, the Western hemisphere surpassed China in scientific and technological advancement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[410]</a></sup> The causes of this early modern <a href="/wiki/Great_Divergence" title="Great Divergence">Great Divergence</a> continue to be debated by scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p>After repeated <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">military defeats</a> by the European colonial powers and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_war" title="First Sino-Japanese war">Japan</a> in the 19th century, Chinese reformers began promoting modern science and technology as part of the <a href="/wiki/Self-Strengthening_Movement" title="Self-Strengthening Movement">Self-Strengthening Movement</a>. After the Communists came to power in 1949, efforts were made to organize science and technology based on the model of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, in which scientific research was part of central planning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[412]</a></sup> After Mao's death in 1976, science and technology was promoted as one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Modernizations" title="Four Modernizations">Four Modernizations</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[413]</a></sup> and the Soviet-inspired academic system was gradually reformed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[414]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Huawei_1.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2126" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Huawei_1.JPG/220px-Huawei_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Huawei_1.JPG/330px-Huawei_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Huawei_1.JPG/440px-Huawei_1.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Huawei_1.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>. Huawei is the world's largest telecoms-equipment-maker and the second-largest manufacturer of <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[415]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since the end of the Cultural Revolution, China has made significant investments in scientific research<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CWRD_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-CWRD-443">[416]</a></sup> and is quickly catching up with the US in R&amp;D spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[418]</a></sup> In 2017, China spent $279 billion on scientific research and development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[419]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, China spent 2.11% of its GDP on research and development (R&amp;D) in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[420]</a></sup> Science and technology are seen as vital for achieving China's economic and political goals, and are held as a source of national pride to a degree sometimes described as "techno-nationalism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TeNat_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-TeNat-448">[421]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Indicators" title="World Intellectual Property Indicators">World Intellectual Property Indicators</a>, China received 1.54 million patent applications in 2018, representing nearly half of patent applications worldwide, more than double the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[422]</a></sup> In 2019, China was No. 1 in international patents application.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[423]</a></sup> China was ranked 11th, 3rd in Asia &amp; Oceania region and 2nd for countries with a population of over 100 million in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2022, it has increased its ranking considerably since 2013, where it was ranked 35th.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[427]</a></sup> China ranks first globally in the important indicators, including patents, utility models, trademarks, industrial designs, and creative goods exports and it also has 2 (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guangdong-Hong_Kong-Macau_Greater_Bay_Area" title="Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area">Shenzhen-Hong Kong-Guangzhou</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a> in the 2nd and 3rd spots respectively) of the global top 5 science and technology clusters, which is more than any other country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_455-0"><a
