href="#cite_note-:10-455">[428]</a></sup> Chinese tech companies <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/ZTE" title="ZTE">ZTE</a> were the top 2 filers of international patents in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[430]</a></sup> Chinese-born academicians have won the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> four times, the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a> once respectively, though most of them conducted their prize-winning research in western nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[ab]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Synthesis_of_published_material" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag may be based upon an improper synthesis of sources. (July 2020)">improper synthesis?</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4608" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg/220px-Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg/330px-Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg/440px-Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Launch_of_Shenzhou_13.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Long_March_2F" title="Long March 2F">Long March 2F</a> launching <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shenzhou_spacecraft" title="Shenzhou spacecraft">Shenzhou spacecraft</a>. China is one of the only three countries with independent <a href="/wiki/Human_spaceflight" title="Human spaceflight">human spaceflight</a> capability.</div></div></div>
<p>China is developing <a href="/wiki/Education_in_China" title="Education in China">its education system</a> with an emphasis on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/STEM_fields" title="STEM fields">science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM)</a>; in 2009, China graduated over 10,000 PhD engineers, and as many as 500,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BSc" title="BSc">BSc</a> graduates, more than any other country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[437]</a></sup> China also became the world's largest publisher of <a href="/wiki/Academic_publishing_in_China" title="Academic publishing in China">scientific papers</a> since 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[440]</a></sup> Chinese technology companies such as Huawei, Xiaomi and <a href="/wiki/Lenovo" title="Lenovo">Lenovo</a> have become world leaders in telecommunications, consumer electronics and personal computing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[443]</a></sup> and Chinese <a href="/wiki/Supercomputer" title="Supercomputer">supercomputers</a> are consistently ranked among the <a href="/wiki/TOP500" title="TOP500">world's most powerful</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[445]</a></sup> China has been the world's largest market for industrial robots since 2013 and will account for 45% of newly installed robots from 2019 to 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_space_program" title="Chinese space program">Chinese space program</a> is one of the world's most active. In 1970, China launched its first satellite, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dong_Fang_Hong_I" title="Dong Fang Hong I">Dong Fang Hong I</a>, becoming the fifth country to do so independently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[447]</a></sup> In 2003, China became the first country in Asia and the third country in the world to independently send humans into space, with <a href="/wiki/Yang_Liwei" title="Yang Liwei">Yang Liwei</a>'s spaceflight aboard <a href="/wiki/Shenzhou_5" title="Shenzhou 5">Shenzhou 5</a>; as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_astronauts" title="List of Chinese astronauts">fourteen Chinese nationals</a> have journeyed into space, including two women. In 2011, China launched its first space station testbed, <a href="/wiki/Tiangong-1" title="Tiangong-1">Tiangong-1</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[448]</a></sup> In 2013, China successfully landed the <a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_3" title="Chang'e 3">Chang'e 3</a> lander and <a href="/wiki/Yutu_(rover)" title="Yutu (rover)">Yutu</a> rover onto the lunar surface.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[449]</a></sup> In 2016, the first <a href="/wiki/Quantum_Experiments_at_Space_Scale" title="Quantum Experiments at Space Scale">quantum science satellite</a> was launched in partnership with <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> dedicated to testing the fundamentals of quantum communication in space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[451]</a></sup> In 2019, China became the first country to land a probe—<a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_4" title="Chang'e 4">Chang'e 4</a>—on the <a href="/wiki/Far_side_of_the_Moon" title="Far side of the Moon">Far side of the Moon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[452]</a></sup> In 2020, the first experimental <a href="/wiki/6G_(network)" title="6G (network)">6G</a> test satellite was launched<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[454]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_5" title="Chang'e 5">Chang'e 5</a> successfully returned moon samples to the Earth, making China the third country to do so independently after the United States and the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[455]</a></sup> In 2021, China became the second nation in history to independently land a <a href="/wiki/Zhurong_(rover)" title="Zhurong (rover)">rover (Zhurong)</a> on Mars, joining the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[456]</a></sup>
</p><p>Currently, China is building its own space station, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiangong_Space_Station" title="Tiangong Space Station"><i>Tiangong</i></a>, in <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a>. The construction of the space station is targeted to be completed by the end of 2022 with the launch of two new modules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CSSplan_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-CSSplan-485">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<p>After a decades-long infrastructural boom,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[458]</a></sup> China has produced numerous world-leading infrastructural projects: China has the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_by_country" title="High-speed rail by country">world's largest bullet train network</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[459]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_supertall_skyscrapers" title="List of supertall skyscrapers">most supertall skyscrapers</a> in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[460]</a></sup> the world's largest power plant (the <a href="/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam" title="Three Gorges Dam">Three Gorges Dam</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[461]</a></sup> the largest energy generation capacity in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[462]</a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/BeiDou" title="BeiDou">global satellite navigation system</a> with the largest number of satellites in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[463]</a></sup> and has initiated the <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a>, a large global infrastructure building initiative with funding on the order of $50–100 billion per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[464]</a></sup> The Belt and Road Initiative could be one of the largest development plans in modern history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[465]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_China" title="Telecommunications in China">Telecommunications in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P1994-2011.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="525" data-file-width="590" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/P1994-2011.gif/280px-P1994-2011.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/P1994-2011.gif/420px-P1994-2011.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/P1994-2011.gif/560px-P1994-2011.gif 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P1994-2011.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Internet penetration rates in China in the context of <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, 1995–2012</div></div></div>
<p>China is the largest telecom market in the world and currently has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_mobile_phones_in_use" title="List of countries by number of mobile phones in use">largest number of active cellphones</a> of any country in the world, with over 1.5 billion subscribers, as of 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[466]</a></sup> It also has the world's largest number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">internet</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_broadband_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of broadband Internet users">broadband users</a>, with over 800 million Internet users as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>—equivalent to around 60% of its population—and almost all of them being mobile as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[467]</a></sup> By 2018, China had more than 1 billion 4G users, accounting for 40% of world's total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[468]</a></sup> China is making rapid advances in <a href="/wiki/5G" title="5G">5G</a>—by late 2018, China had started large-scale and commercial 5G trials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[469]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China_Mobile" title="China Mobile">China Mobile</a>, <a href="/wiki/China_Unicom" title="China Unicom">China Unicom</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_Telecom" title="China Telecom">China Telecom</a>, are the three large providers of mobile and internet in China. China Telecom alone served more than 145 million broadband subscribers and 300 million mobile users; China Unicom had about 300 million subscribers; and China Mobile, the largest of them all, had 925 million users, as of 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[471]</a></sup> Combined, the three operators had over 3.4 million 4G base-stations in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-500">[472]</a></sup> Several Chinese telecommunications companies, most notably <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/ZTE" title="ZTE">ZTE</a>, have been accused of spying for the Chinese military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[473]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has developed its own <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">satellite navigation</a> system, dubbed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BeiDou_Navigation_Satellite_System" title="BeiDou Navigation Satellite System">Beidou</a>, which began offering commercial navigation services across Asia in 2012<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CustomersDec2012_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-CustomersDec2012-502">[474]</a></sup> as well as global services by the end of 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[476]</a></sup> Upon the completion of the 35th Beidou satellite, which was launched into orbit on 23 June 2020, Beidou followed <a href="/wiki/Global_Positioning_System" title="Global Positioning System">GPS</a> and <a href="/wiki/GLONASS" title="GLONASS">GLONASS</a> as the third completed global navigation satellite in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[477]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_China" title="Transport in China">Transport in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Duge_Bridge.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Duge_Bridge.jpg/200px-Duge_Bridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Duge_Bridge.jpg/300px-Duge_Bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Duge_Bridge.jpg/400px-Duge_Bridge.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Duge_Bridge.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Duge_Bridge" title="Duge Bridge">Duge Bridge</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest_bridges" title="List of highest bridges">highest bridge in the world</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the late 1990s, China's national road network has been significantly expanded through the creation of a network of <a href="/wiki/China_National_Highways" title="China National Highways">national highways</a> and <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_China" title="Expressways of China">expressways</a>. In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_China" title="Expressways of China">China's highways</a> had reached a total length of 142,500 km (88,500 mi), making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">longest highway system in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[478]</a></sup> China has the world's largest market for automobiles, having surpassed the United States in both auto sales and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">production</a>. A side-effect of the rapid growth of China's road network has been a significant rise in traffic accidents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[479]</a></sup> though the number of fatalities in traffic accidents fell by 20% from 2007 to 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[480]</a></sup> In urban areas, bicycles remain a common mode of transport, despite the increasing prevalence of automobiles – as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are approximately 470 million bicycles in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470MBikes_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-509">[481]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_New_Airport.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2962" data-file-width="5272" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Beijing_New_Airport.jpg/200px-Beijing_New_Airport.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Beijing_New_Airport.jpg/300px-Beijing_New_Airport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Beijing_New_Airport.jpg/400px-Beijing_New_Airport.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_New_Airport.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport" title="Beijing Daxing International Airport">Beijing Daxing International Airport</a> features the world's largest single-building airport terminal.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_China" title="Rail transport in China">China's railways</a>, which are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_Railway_Corporation" title="China Railway Corporation">state-owned</a>, are among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rail_usage_statistics_by_country" title="Rail usage statistics by country">the busiest in the world</a>, handling a quarter of the world's rail traffic volume on only 6 percent of the world's tracks in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[482]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (January 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> As of 2017, the country had 127,000 km (78,914 mi) of railways, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size" title="List of countries by rail transport network size">second longest network in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_stats_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013_stats-511">[483]</a></sup> The railways strain to meet enormous demand particularly during the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_New_Year" title="Chinese New Year">Chinese New Year</a> holiday, when the <a href="/wiki/Chunyun" title="Chunyun">world's largest annual human migration</a> takes place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overcrowding_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-overcrowding-512">[484]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_China" title="High-speed rail in China">high-speed rail (HSR) system</a> started construction in the early 2000s. By the end of 2020, <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_China" title="High-speed rail in China">high speed rail in China</a> had reached 37,900 kilometers (23,550 miles) of dedicated lines alone, making it the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_by_country" title="High-speed rail by country">longest HSR network in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[486]</a></sup> Services on the <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Shanghai_high-speed_railway" title="Beijing–Shanghai high-speed railway">Beijing–Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Tianjin_intercity_railway" title="Beijing–Tianjin intercity railway">Beijing–Tianjin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chengdu%E2%80%93Chongqing_intercity_railway" title="Chengdu–Chongqing intercity railway">Chengdu–Chongqing</a> Lines reach up to 350 km/h (217 mph), making them the fastest conventional high speed railway services in the world. With an annual ridership of over 2.29 billion passengers in 2019 it is the world's busiest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[487]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The network includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Guangzhou%E2%80%93Shenzhen%E2%80%93Hong_Kong_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen–Hong Kong High-Speed Railway">Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen High-Speed Railway</a>, the single longest HSR line in the world, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Shanghai_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing–Shanghai High-Speed Railway">Beijing–Shanghai High-Speed Railway</a>, which has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_longest_bridges_in_the_world" title="List of longest bridges in the world">three of longest railroad bridges in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[488]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Maglev_Train" title="Shanghai Maglev Train">Shanghai Maglev Train</a>, which reaches 431 km/h (268 mph), is the fastest commercial train service in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[489]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg/220px-Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg/330px-Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg/440px-Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yangshan_Port_20170923-3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shanghai" title="Port of Shanghai">Port of Shanghai</a>'s deep water harbor on <a href="/wiki/Yangshan_Port" title="Yangshan Port">Yangshan Island</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou_Bay" title="Hangzhou Bay">Hangzhou Bay</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">world's busiest container port</a> since 2010.</div></div></div>
<p>Since 2000, the growth of rapid transit systems in Chinese cities has accelerated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[490]</a></sup> As of January 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 44 Chinese cities have <a href="/wiki/Urban_rail_transit_in_China" title="Urban rail transit in China">urban mass transit systems</a> in operation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[491]</a></sup> and 39 more have metro systems approved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[492]</a></sup> As of 2020, China boasts the five longest <a href="/wiki/List_of_metro_systems" title="List of metro systems">metro systems in the world</a> with the networks in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou_Metro" title="Guangzhou Metro">Guangzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_Metro" title="Chengdu Metro">Chengdu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen_Metro" title="Shenzhen Metro">Shenzhen</a> being the largest.
</p><p>There were <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_China" title="List of airports in China">approximately 229 airports in 2017</a>, with around 240 planned by 2020. China has over 2,000 <a href="/wiki/List_of_ports_in_China" title="List of ports in China">river and seaports</a>, about 130 of which are open to foreign shipping.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[493]</a></sup> In 2017, the Ports of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shanghai" title="Port of Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Hong_Kong" title="Port of Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shenzhen" title="Port of Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ningbo-Zhoushan" title="Port of Ningbo-Zhoushan">Ningbo-Zhoushan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Guangzhou" title="Port of Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_of_Qingdao" title="Port of Qingdao">Qingdao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tianjin" title="Port of Tianjin">Tianjin</a> ranked in the Top 10 in the world <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">in container traffic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">cargo tonnage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[494]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_China" title="Water supply and sanitation in China">Water supply and sanitation in China</a></div>
<p>Water supply and sanitation infrastructure in China is facing challenges such as rapid urbanization, as well as <a href="/wiki/Water_resources_of_China" title="Water resources of China">water scarcity, contamination, and pollution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_Scarcity_in_China_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_Scarcity_in_China-523">[495]</a></sup> According to data presented by the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Monitoring_Programme_for_Water_Supply_and_Sanitation" title="Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation">Joint Monitoring Program for Water Supply and Sanitation</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">WHO</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> in 2015, about 36% of the rural population in China still did not have access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[496]</a></sup> The ongoing <a href="/wiki/South%E2%80%93North_Water_Transfer_Project" title="South–North Water Transfer Project">South–North Water Transfer Project</a> intends to abate water shortage in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-forbes-525">[497]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_China" title="Demographics of China">Demographics of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PRC_Population_Density.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="857" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/220px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/330px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/440px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PRC_Population_Density.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 2009 population density map of the People's Republic of China, with territories not under its control in blue. The eastern coastal provinces are much more densely populated than the western interior.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/2020_Chinese_census" title="2020 Chinese census">national census of 2020</a> recorded the <a href="/wiki/Population" title="Population">population</a> of the People's Republic of China as approximately 1,411,778,724. According to the 2020 census, about 17.95% of the population were 14 years old or younger, 63.35% were between 15 and 59 years old, and 18.7% were over 60 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020_census_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-2020_census-17">[10]</a></sup> The population growth rate for 2013 is estimated to be 0.46%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[498]</a></sup> China used to make up much of the world's poor; now it makes up much of the world's middle class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[499]</a></sup> Although a middle-income country by Western standards, China's rapid growth has <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_China" title="Poverty in China">pulled hundreds of millions</a>—800 million, to be more precise<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[500]</a></sup>—of its people out of poverty since 1978. By 2013, less than 2% of the Chinese population lived below the international poverty line of US$1.9 per day, down from 88% in 1981.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_380-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-380">[353]</a></sup> From 2009 to 2018, the unemployment rate in China has averaged about 4%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[501]</a></sup>
</p><p>Given concerns about population growth, China implemented a two-child limit during the 1970s, and, in 1979, began to advocate for an even stricter limit of one child per family. Beginning in the mid-1980s, however, given the unpopularity of the strict limits, China began to allow some major exemptions, particularly in rural areas, resulting in what was actually a "1.5"-child policy from the mid-1980s to 2015 (ethnic minorities were also exempt from one child limits). The next major loosening of the policy was enacted in December 2013, allowing families to have two children if one parent is an only child.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[502]</a></sup> In 2016, the one-child policy was replaced in favor of a <a href="/wiki/Two-child_policy" title="Two-child policy">two-child policy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[503]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Three-child_policy" title="Three-child policy">three-child policy</a> was announced on 31 May 2021, due to <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_China" title="Aging of China">population aging</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[504]</a></sup> and in July 2021, all family size limits as well as penalties for exceeding them were removed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[505]</a></sup> According to data from the 2020 census, China's total fertility rate is 1.3, but some experts believe that after adjusting for the transient effects of the relaxation of restrictions, the country's actual total fertility rate is as low as 1.1.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[506]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to one group of scholars, one-child limits had little effect on population growth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wang_Judge_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wang_Judge-535">[507]</a></sup> or the size of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whyte_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-Whyte-536">[508]</a></sup> However, these scholars have been challenged. Their own counterfactual model of fertility decline without such restrictions implies that China averted more than 500 million births between 1970 and 2015, a number which may reach one billion by 2060 given all the lost descendants of births averted during the era of fertility restrictions, with one-child restrictions accounting for the great bulk of that reduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[509]</a></sup> The policy, along with traditional preference for boys, may have contributed to an imbalance in the <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratio</a> at birth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[510]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2007a_539-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2007a-539">[511]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, the sex ratio at birth was 118.06 boys for every 100 girls,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-540">[512]</a></sup> which is beyond the normal range of around 105 boys for every 100 girls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[513]</a></sup> The 2010 census found that males accounted for 51.27 percent of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_540-1"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-540">[512]</a></sup> However, China's sex ratio is more balanced than it was in 1953, when males accounted for 51.82 percent of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_540-2"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-540">[512]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_China" title="List of ethnic groups in China">List of ethnic groups in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_China" title="Ethnic minorities in China">Ethnic minorities in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Chinese_history" title="Ethnic groups in Chinese history">Ethnic groups in Chinese history</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2544" data-file-width="3031" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg/220px-China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg/330px-China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg/440px-China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_ethnolinguistic_1967.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethnolinguistic map of China</div></div></div>
<p>China legally recognizes 56 distinct ethnic groups, who altogether comprise the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhonghua_Minzu" title="Zhonghua Minzu">Zhonghua Minzu</a></i>. The largest of these nationalities are the ethnic Chinese or "Han", who constitute more than 90% of the total
population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-groups-542">[514]</a></sup> The Han Chinese – the world's largest single ethnic group<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[515]</a></sup> – outnumber other ethnic groups in every provincial-level division except <a href="/wiki/Tibet_Autonomous_Region" title="Tibet Autonomous Region">Tibet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[516]</a></sup> Ethnic minorities account for less than 10% of the population of China, according to the 2010 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_542-1"><a href="#cite_note-groups-542">[514]</a></sup> Compared with the 2000 population census, the Han population increased by 66,537,177 persons, or 5.74%, while the population of the 55 national minorities combined increased by 7,362,627 persons, or 6.92%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_542-2"><a href="#cite_note-groups-542">[514]</a></sup> The 2010 census recorded a total of 593,832 foreign nationals living in China. The largest such groups were from South Korea (120,750), the
United States (71,493) and Japan (66,159).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[517]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_China" title="Languages of China">Languages of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_China" title="List of endangered languages in China">List of endangered languages in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Post_logo_with_(New)_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan,_Yunnan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="481" data-file-width="1616" decoding="async" height="65" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/220px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/330px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/440px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Post_logo_with_(New)_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan,_Yunnan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A trilingual sign in <a href="/wiki/Xishuangbanna_Dai_Autonomous_Prefecture" title="Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture">Sibsongbanna</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tai_L%C3%BC_language" title="Tai Lü language">Tai Lü language</a> on the top</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG/200px-Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG/300px-Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG/400px-Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lihaozhai_High_School_-_P1360829.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lihaozhai High School in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jianshui" title="Jianshui">Jianshui</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a>. The sign is in <a href="/wiki/Hani_language" title="Hani language">Hani</a> (Latin alphabet), <a href="/wiki/Nisu_language" title="Nisu language">Nisu</a> (<a href="/wiki/Yi_script" title="Yi script">Yi script</a>), and Chinese.</div></div></div>
<p>There are as many as 292 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Living_language" title="Living language">living languages</a> in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[518]</a></sup> The languages most commonly spoken belong to the <a href="/wiki/Sinitic_languages" title="Sinitic languages">Sinitic branch</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino-Tibetan_language" title="Sino-Tibetan language">Sino-Tibetan language</a> family, which contains <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin</a> (spoken by 70% of the population),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[519]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">other varieties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese language</a>: <a href="/wiki/Yue_Chinese" title="Yue Chinese">Yue</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taishanese" title="Taishanese">Taishanese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">Wu</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Shanghainese" title="Shanghainese">Shanghainese</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suzhounese" title="Suzhounese">Suzhounese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Min_Chinese" title="Min Chinese">Min</a> (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuzhounese" title="Fuzhounese">Fuzhounese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Teochew_dialect" title="Teochew dialect">Teochew</a>), <a href="/wiki/Xiang_Chinese" title="Xiang Chinese">Xiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gan_Chinese" title="Gan Chinese">Gan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakka_language" title="Hakka language">Hakka</a>. Languages of the <a href="/wiki/Tibeto-Burman_languages" title="Tibeto-Burman languages">Tibeto-Burman branch</a>, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Tibetan" title="Standard Tibetan">Tibetan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qiang_language" title="Qiang language">Qiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naxi_language" title="Naxi language">Naxi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yi_language" title="Yi language">Yi</a>, are spoken across the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau" title="Tibetan Plateau">Tibetan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yunnan%E2%80%93Guizhou_Plateau" title="Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau">Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau</a>. Other ethnic minority languages in <a href="/wiki/Southwest_China" title="Southwest China">southwest China</a> include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhuang_language" title="Zhuang language">Zhuang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_language" title="Thai language">Thai</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dong_language_(China)" title="Dong language (China)">Dong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sui_language" title="Sui language">Sui</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tai%E2%80%93Kadai_languages" title="Tai–Kadai languages">Tai-Kadai family</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hmongic_language" title="Hmongic language">Miao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mienic_languages" title="Mienic languages">Yao</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hmong%E2%80%93Mien_languages" title="Hmong–Mien languages">Hmong–Mien family</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wa_language" title="Wa language">Wa</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_Languages" title="Austroasiatic Languages">Austroasiatic family</a>. Across <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_China" title="Northeastern China">northeastern</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northwestern_China" title="Northwestern China">northwestern China</a>, local ethnic groups speak <a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic languages</a> including <a href="/wiki/Manchu_language" title="Manchu language">Manchu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_language" title="Mongolian language">Mongolian</a> and several <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a>: <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_language" title="Uyghur language">Uyghur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakh_language" title="Kazakh language">Kazakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_language" title="Kyrgyz language">Kyrgyz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salar_language" title="Salar language">Salar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Yugur_language" title="Western Yugur language">Western Yugur</a>. <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a> is spoken natively along the border with <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. <a href="/wiki/Sarikoli_language" title="Sarikoli language">Sarikoli</a>, the language of <a href="/wiki/Tajiks_of_Xinjiang" title="Tajiks of Xinjiang">Tajiks in western Xinjiang</a>, is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" title="Taiwanese aborigines">Taiwanese aborigines</a>, including a small population on the mainland, speak <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-language_548-0"><a href="#cite_note-language-548">[520]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Mandarin" title="Standard Mandarin">Standard Mandarin</a>, a variety of Mandarin based on the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_dialect" title="Beijing dialect">Beijing dialect</a>, is the official national language of China and is used as a <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> in the country between people of different linguistic backgrounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-langlaw_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-langlaw-549">[521]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[522]</a></sup> Mongolian, Uyghur, Tibetan, Zhuang and various other languages are also regionally recognized throughout the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[523]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> have been used as the <a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">written script</a> for the Sinitic languages for thousands of years. They allow speakers of mutually unintelligible Chinese varieties to communicate with each other through writing. In 1956, the government introduced <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified characters</a>, which have supplanted the older <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional characters</a> in mainland China. Chinese characters are <a href="/wiki/Romanization" title="Romanization">romanized</a> using the <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">Pinyin system</a>. Tibetan uses an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tibetan_alphabet" title="Tibetan alphabet">alphabet</a> based on an <a href="/wiki/Brahmic_scripts" title="Brahmic scripts">Indic script</a>. Uyghur is most commonly written in <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Persian alphabet</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_Arabic_alphabet" title="Uyghur Arabic alphabet">Uyghur Arabic alphabet</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_script" title="Mongolian script">Mongolian script used in China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Manchu_alphabet" title="Manchu alphabet">Manchu script</a> are both derived from the <a href="/wiki/Old_Uyghur_alphabet" title="Old Uyghur alphabet">Old Uyghur alphabet</a>. <a href="/wiki/Zhuang_languages" title="Zhuang languages">Zhuang</a> uses both an official <a href="/wiki/Standard_Zhuang" title="Standard Zhuang">Latin alphabet script</a> and a traditional <a href="/wiki/Sawndip" title="Sawndip">Chinese character script</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China" title="List of cities in China">List of cities in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">List of cities in China by population</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Megalopolises_in_China" title="Megalopolises in China">Megalopolises in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="930" data-file-width="1058" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/200px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/300px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/400px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the ten <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">largest cities</a> in China (2010)</div></div></div>
<p>China has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urbanisation" title="Urbanisation">urbanized</a> significantly in recent decades. The percent of the country's population living in urban areas increased from 20% in 1980 to over 60% in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[524]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_553-0"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-553">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinasUrbanFuture_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinasUrbanFuture-554">[526]</a></sup> It is estimated that China's urban population will reach one billion by 2030, potentially equivalent to one-eighth of the world population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_553-1"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-553">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinasUrbanFuture_554-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChinasUrbanFuture-554">[526]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has over 160 cities with a population of over one million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[527]</a></sup> including the 17 <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacities</a> as of 2021<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[528]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[529]</a></sup> (cities with a population of over 10 million) of <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chengdu" title="Chengdu">Chengdu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xi%27an" title="Xi'an">Xi'an</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suzhou" title="Suzhou">Suzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhengzhou" title="Zhengzhou">Zhengzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou" title="Hangzhou">Hangzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Linyi" title="Linyi">Linyi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shijiazhuang" title="Shijiazhuang">Shijiazhuang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dongguan" title="Dongguan">Dongguan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qingdao" title="Qingdao">Qingdao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Changsha" title="Changsha">Changsha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[530]</a></sup> Among them, the total permanent population of Chongqing, Shanghai, Beijing and Chengdu is above 20 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[531]</a></sup> Shanghai is China's <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">most populous urban area</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Demographia2013_560-0"><a href="#cite_note-Demographia2013-560">[532]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_561-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-561">[533]</a></sup> while Chongqing is its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_proper_by_population" title="List of cities proper by population">largest city proper</a>, the only city in China with the largest permanent population of over 30 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-renamed_from_2015_on_20160214005959_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-renamed_from_2015_on_20160214005959-562">[534]</a></sup> By 2025, it is estimated that the country will be home to 221 cities with over a million inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_553-2"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-553">[525]</a></sup> The figures in the table below are from the 2017 census,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-census-563">[535]</a></sup> and are only estimates of the urban populations within administrative city limits; a different ranking exists when considering the total municipal populations (which includes suburban and rural populations). The large "<a href="/wiki/Floating_population" title="Floating population">floating populations</a>" of migrant workers make conducting censuses in urban areas difficult;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abce_564-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abce-564">[536]</a></sup> the figures below include only long-term residents.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">
