<li id="cite_note-567"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-567">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Population of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> as of 2018 estimate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationHK_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-populationHK-566">[538]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-569"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-569">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The data of Chongqing in the list is the data of "Metropolitan Developed Economic Area", which contains two parts: "City Proper" and "Metropolitan Area". The "City proper" are consist of 9 districts: <a href="/wiki/Yuzhong_District" title="Yuzhong District">Yuzhong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dadukou_District" title="Dadukou District">Dadukou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiangbei_District,_Chongqing" title="Jiangbei District, Chongqing">Jiangbei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shapingba_District" title="Shapingba District">Shapingba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiulongpo_District" title="Jiulongpo District">Jiulongpo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nan%27an_District" title="Nan'an District">Nan'an</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beibei_District" title="Beibei District">Beibei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yubei_District" title="Yubei District">Yubei</a>, &amp; <a href="/wiki/Banan_District,_Chongqing" title="Banan District, Chongqing">Banan</a>, has the urban population of 5,646,300 as of 2018. And the "Metropolitan Area" are consist of 12 districts: <a href="/wiki/Fuling_District" title="Fuling District">Fuling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Changshou_District" title="Changshou District">Changshou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiangjin_District" title="Jiangjin District">Jiangjin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hechuan_District" title="Hechuan District">Hechuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yongchuan_District" title="Yongchuan District">Yongchuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nanchuan_District" title="Nanchuan District">Nanchuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qijiang_District" title="Qijiang District">Qijiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dazu_District" title="Dazu District">Dazu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bishan_District" title="Bishan District">Bishan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tongliang_District" title="Tongliang District">Tongliang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tongnan_District" title="Tongnan District">Tongnan</a>, &amp; <a href="/wiki/Rongchang_District" title="Rongchang District">Rongchang</a>, has the urban population of 5,841,700.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[539]</a></sup> Total urban population of all 26 districts of Chongqing are up to 15,076,600.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_China" title="Education in China">Education in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_China" title="Higher education in China">Higher education in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_China" title="List of universities in China">List of universities in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:13_Peking_University.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/13_Peking_University.jpg/220px-13_Peking_University.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/13_Peking_University.jpg/330px-13_Peking_University.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/13_Peking_University.jpg/440px-13_Peking_University.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:13_Peking_University.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Peking_University" title="Peking University">Peking University</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_China" title="Rankings of universities in China">top-ranked universities in China</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[540]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[541]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since 1986, compulsory education in China comprises <a href="/wiki/Primary_school" title="Primary school">primary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">junior secondary school</a>, which together last for nine years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[542]</a></sup> In 2021, about 91.4 percent of students continued their education at a three-year senior secondary school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[543]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gaokao" title="Gaokao">Gaokao</a>, China's national university entrance exam, is a prerequisite for entrance into most higher education institutions. In 2010, 24 percent of secondary school graduates were enrolled in higher education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[544]</a></sup> This number increased significantly over the last decades, reaching a tertiary school enrolment of 58.42 percent in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575"><a href="#cite_note-575">[545]</a></sup> Vocational education is available to students at the secondary and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary</a> level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-576">[546]</a></sup> More than 10 million Chinese students graduated from vocational colleges nationwide every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[547]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has the largest education system in the world, with about 282 million students and 17.32 million full-time teachers in over 530,000 schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:11_578-0"><a href="#cite_note-:11-578">[548]</a></sup> In February 2006, the government pledged to provide completely free nine-year education, including textbooks and fees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abch_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abch-579">[549]</a></sup> Annual education investment went from less than US$50 billion in 2003 to more than US$817 billion in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[550]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[551]</a></sup> However, there remains an inequality in education spending. In 2010, the annual education expenditure per secondary school student in Beijing totalled ¥20,023, while in <a href="/wiki/Guizhou" title="Guizhou">Guizhou</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP_per_capita" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP per capita">poorest provinces in China</a>, only totalled ¥3,204.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[552]</a></sup> Free compulsory education in China consists of primary school and junior secondary school between the ages of 6 and 15. In 2020, the graduation enrollment ratio at compulsory education level reached 95.2 percent, exceeding average levels recorded in high-income countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:11_578-1"><a href="#cite_note-:11-578">[548]</a></sup> and around 91.2% of Chinese have received secondary education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_576-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-576">[546]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's literacy rate has grown dramatically, from only 20% in 1949 and 65.5% in 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[553]</a></sup> to 97% of the population over age 15 in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[554]</a></sup> In the same year, China (Beijing, Shanghai, <a href="/wiki/Jiangsu" title="Jiangsu">Jiangsu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang" title="Zhejiang">Zhejiang</a>) was ranked the highest in the world in the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> ranking for all three categories of Mathematics, Science and Reading.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[555]</a></sup> As of 2022, China ranks first in the all-time medal count at the <a href="/wiki/International_Mathematical_Olympiad" title="International Mathematical Olympiad">International Mathematical Olympiad</a> with 174 goal medals since its first participation in 1985.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[556]</a></sup> China also ranks first in the all-time medal count at the <a href="/wiki/International_Physics_Olympiad" title="International Physics Olympiad">International Physics Olympiad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Chemistry_Olympiad" title="International Chemistry Olympiad">International Chemistry Olympiad</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympiad_in_Informatics" title="International Olympiad in Informatics">International Olympiad in Informatics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[559]</a></sup>
</p><p>China had over 3,000 universities, with over 40 million students enrolled in mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[560]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[561]</a></sup> As of 2021, China had the world's second-highest <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_China" title="Rankings of universities in China">number of top universities</a> (the highest in Asia &amp; Oceania region).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[562]</a></sup> Currently, China trails only the United States in terms of representation on lists of top 200 universities according to the <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a> (ARWU).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[563]</a></sup> China is home to the two of the highest ranking universities (<a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peking_University" title="Peking University">Peking University</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging economies</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[564]</a></sup> As of 2022, two universities in Mainland China rank in the world's top 15, with Peking University (12th) and Tsinghua University (14th) and three other universities ranking in the world's top 50, namely <a href="/wiki/Fudan_University" title="Fudan University">Fudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang_University" title="Zhejiang University">Zhejiang</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Jiao_Tong_University" title="Shanghai Jiao Tong University">Shanghai Jiao Tong</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[565]</a></sup> These universities are members of the <a href="/wiki/C9_League" title="C9 League">C9 League</a>, an alliance of elite <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_universities" title="Chinese universities">Chinese universities</a> offering comprehensive and leading education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[566]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_China" title="Health in China">Health in China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Medicine_in_China" title="Medicine in China">Medicine in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_China" title="Pharmaceutical industry in China">Pharmaceutical industry in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_mainland_China" title="COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China">COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="295" data-file-width="438" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/200px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/300px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/400px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chart showing the rise of China's <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> from 1970 to 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Health_and_Family_Planning_Commission" title="National Health and Family Planning Commission">National Health and Family Planning Commission</a>, together with its counterparts in the local commissions, oversees the health needs of the Chinese population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[567]</a></sup> An emphasis on public health and preventive medicine has characterized Chinese health policy since the early 1950s. At that time, the Communist Party started the <a href="/wiki/Patriotic_Health_Campaign" title="Patriotic Health Campaign">Patriotic Health Campaign</a>, which was aimed at improving sanitation and hygiene, as well as treating and preventing several diseases. Diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Typhoid" title="Typhoid">typhoid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_fever" title="Scarlet fever">scarlet fever</a>, which were previously rife in China, were nearly eradicated by the campaign.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> began instituting <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms</a> in 1978, the health of the Chinese public improved rapidly because of better nutrition, although many of the free public health services provided in the countryside disappeared along with the People's Communes. Healthcare in China became mostly privatized, and experienced a significant rise in quality. In 2009, the government began a 3-year large-scale healthcare provision initiative worth US$124 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[568]</a></sup> By 2011, the campaign resulted in 95% of China's population having basic health insurance coverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[569]</a></sup> In 2011, China was estimated to be the world's third-largest supplier of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, but its population has suffered from the development and distribution of <a href="/wiki/Counterfeit_medications" title="Counterfeit medications">counterfeit medications</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[570]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the average life expectancy at birth in China is 76 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601"><a href="#cite_note-601">[571]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate is 7 per thousand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[572]</a></sup> Both have improved significantly since the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[ac]</a></sup> Rates of <a href="/wiki/Stunted_growth" title="Stunted growth">stunting</a>, a condition caused by <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, have declined from 33.1% in 1990 to 9.9% in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[575]</a></sup> Despite significant improvements in health and the construction of advanced medical facilities, China has several emerging public health problems, such as respiratory illnesses caused by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_China" title="Air pollution in China">widespread air pollution</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT-china-pollution_607-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT-china-pollution-607">[576]</a></sup> hundreds of millions of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_smoking" title="Tobacco smoking">cigarette smokers</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[577]</a></sup> and an increase in <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a> among urban youths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcy_609-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcy-609">[578]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcz_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcz-610">[579]</a></sup> China's large population and densely populated cities have led to serious disease outbreaks in recent years, such as the 2003 outbreak of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome">SARS</a>, although this has since been largely contained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcda_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcda-611">[580]</a></sup> In 2010, air pollution caused 1.2 million premature deaths in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[581]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> was first identified in <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a> in December 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto12_613-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto12-613">[582]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[583]</a></sup> Further studies are being carried out around the world on a possible origin for the virus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[584]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-616"><a href="#cite_note-616">[585]</a></sup> The Chinese government has been criticized for its handling of the epidemic and accused of concealing the extent of the outbreak before it became an international pandemic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[586]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_China" title="Religion in China">Religion in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2167" data-file-width="3109" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png/300px-Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png/450px-Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png/600px-Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Distribution_of_religions_in_China.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><small>Geographic distribution of religions in China.</small><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map1_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-map1-618">[587]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map2_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-map2-619">[588]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map3_620-0"><a href="#cite_note-map3-620">[589]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map4_621-0"><a href="#cite_note-map4-621">[590]</a></sup><br/><span style="color:#C00000; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#c00000">■</span> <small><a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">Chinese folk religion</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, and groups of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese Buddhism</a>)</small><br/><span style="color:#FFFF00; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#ffff00">■</span> <small><a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> <i>tout court</i></small><br/><span style="color:#008000; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#008000">■</span> <small><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Islam</a></small><br/><span style="color:#FF00FF; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#ff00ff">■</span> <small><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_China#Ethnic_minorities'_indigenous_religions" title="Religion in China">Ethnic minorities' indigenous religions</a></small><br/><span style="color:#00CCFF; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#00ccff">■</span> <small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongolian_folk_religion" title="Mongolian folk religion">Mongolian folk religion</a></small><br/><span style="color:#00FF00; font-size:100%; line-height:1;" title="#00ff00">■</span> <small><a href="/wiki/Northeast_China_folk_religion" title="Northeast China folk religion">Northeast China folk religion</a> influenced by Tungus and <a href="/wiki/Manchu_shamanism" title="Manchu shamanism">Manchu shamanism</a>; widespread <a href="/wiki/Shanrendao" title="Shanrendao">Shanrendao</a></small></div></div></div>
<p>The government of the People's Republic of China officially espouses <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_atheism_in_China" title="State atheism in China">state atheism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[591]</a></sup> and has conducted <a href="/wiki/Antireligious_campaigns_in_China" title="Antireligious campaigns in China">antireligious campaigns</a> to this end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BuangChew2014_623-0"><a href="#cite_note-BuangChew2014-623">[592]</a></sup> Religious affairs and issues in the country are overseen by the <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_for_Religious_Affairs" title="State Administration for Religious Affairs">State Administration for Religious Affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[593]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">Freedom of religion</a> is guaranteed by China's constitution, although religious organizations that lack official approval can be subject to state persecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_304-1"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-304">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[594]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the millennia, Chinese civilization has been influenced by various religious movements. The "<a href="/wiki/Three_teachings" title="Three teachings">three teachings</a>", including <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese Buddhism</a>), historically have a significant role in shaping Chinese culture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yao2011_626-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yao2011-626">[595]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[596]</a></sup> enriching a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_theology" title="Chinese theology">theological and spiritual framework</a> which harks back to the early <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a>. Chinese popular or folk religion, which is framed by the three teachings and other traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[597]</a></sup> consists in allegiance to the <i><a href="/wiki/Shen_(Chinese_religion)" title="Shen (Chinese religion)">shen</a></i> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%A5%9E" title="wikt:神">神</a></span></span>), a character that signifies the "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_gods_and_immortals" title="Chinese gods and immortals">energies of generation</a>", who can be <a href="/wiki/Deity" title="Deity">deities</a> of the environment or <a href="/wiki/Progenitor" title="Progenitor">ancestral principles</a> of human groups, concepts of civility, <a href="/wiki/Culture_hero" title="Culture hero">culture heroes</a>, many of whom feature in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">Chinese mythology</a> and history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-629"><a href="#cite_note-629">[598]</a></sup> Among the most popular <a href="/wiki/Cult_(religious_practice)" title="Cult (religious practice)">cults</a> are those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mazu_(goddess)" title="Mazu (goddess)">Mazu</a> (goddess of the seas),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laliberte2011_630-0"><a href="#cite_note-Laliberte2011-630">[599]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Emperor" title="Yellow Emperor">Huangdi</a> (one of the two <a href="/wiki/Yan_Huang_Zisun" title="Yan Huang Zisun">divine patriarchs</a> of the Chinese race),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laliberte2011_630-1"><a href="#cite_note-Laliberte2011-630">[599]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[600]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guandi" title="Guandi">Guandi</a> (god of war and business), <a href="/wiki/Caishen" title="Caishen">Caishen</a> (god of prosperity and richness), <a href="/wiki/Pangu" title="Pangu">Pangu</a> and many others. China is home to many of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_statues_by_height" title="List of statues by height">world's tallest religious statues</a>, including the tallest of all, the <a href="/wiki/Spring_Temple_Buddha" title="Spring Temple Buddha">Spring Temple Buddha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Henan" title="Henan">Henan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632"><a href="#cite_note-632">[601]</a></sup>
</p><p>Clear data on religious affiliation in China is difficult to gather due to varying definitions of "religion" and the unorganized, diffusive nature of Chinese religious traditions. Scholars note that in China there is no clear boundary between <a href="/wiki/Three_teachings" title="Three teachings">three teachings</a> religions and local folk religious practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yao2011_626-1"><a href="#cite_note-Yao2011-626">[595]</a></sup> A 2015 poll conducted by <a href="/wiki/WIN/GIA" title="WIN/GIA">Gallup International</a> found that 61% of Chinese people self-identified as "convinced atheist",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GallupInternational_633-0"><a href="#cite_note-GallupInternational-633">[602]</a></sup> though it is worthwhile to note that Chinese religions or some of their strands are definable as <a href="/wiki/Nontheism" title="Nontheism">non-theistic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humanistic" title="Humanistic">humanistic</a> religions, since they do not believe that divine creativity is completely transcendent, but it is inherent in the world and in particular in the human being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[603]</a></sup> According to a 2014 study, approximately 74% are either non-religious or practice Chinese folk belief, 16% are Buddhists, 2% are Christians, 1% are Muslims, and 8% adhere to other religions including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taoists" title="Taoists">Taoists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_salvationist_religions" title="Chinese salvationist religions">folk salvationism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CFPS2014_635-0"><a href="#cite_note-CFPS2014-635">[604]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CZ20172_636-0"><a href="#cite_note-CZ20172-636">[605]</a></sup> In addition to Han people's local religious practices, there are also various <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_China" title="Ethnic minorities in China">ethnic minority groups in China</a> who maintain their <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_China#Ethnic_minorities'_indigenous_religions" title="Religion in China">traditional autochthone religions</a>. The various folk religions today comprise 2–3% of the population, while Confucianism as a religious self-identification is common within the intellectual class. Significant faiths specifically connected to certain ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Islamic religion</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hui_people" title="Hui people">Hui</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uyghur_people" title="Uyghur people">Uyghur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhs_in_China" title="Kazakhs in China">Kazakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_in_China" title="Kyrgyz in China">Kyrgyz</a> and other peoples in Northwest China.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The 2010 population census reported the total number of Muslims in the country as 23.14 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637"><a href="#cite_note-637">[606]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2021 poll from <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a> and the Policy Institute at <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King's College London">King's College London</a> found that 35% of Chinese people said there was tension between different religious groups, which was the second lowest percentage of the 28 countries surveyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-638"><a href="#cite_note-638">[607]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-639"><a href="#cite_note-639">[608]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Culture of the People's Republic of China">Culture of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Temple_of_Heaven,_Beijing,_China_-_010_edit.jpg" title="The Temple of Heaven, a center of heaven worship and an UNESCO World Heritage site, symbolizes the Interactions Between Heaven and Mankind."><img alt="" data-file-height="1945" data-file-width="9027" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg/1000px-Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg/1500px-Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg/2000px-Temple_of_Heaven%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_010_edit.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Temple_of_Heaven,_Beijing,_China_-_010_edit.jpg" title="File:Temple of Heaven, Beijing, China - 010 edit.jpg"> </a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a>, a center of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heaven_worship" title="Heaven worship">heaven worship</a> and an UNESCO World Heritage site, symbolizes the <a href="/wiki/Interactions_Between_Heaven_and_Mankind" title="Interactions Between Heaven and Mankind">Interactions Between Heaven and Mankind</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-640"><a href="#cite_note-640">[609]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fenghuang_old_town.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fenghuang_old_town.JPG/220px-Fenghuang_old_town.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fenghuang_old_town.JPG/330px-Fenghuang_old_town.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fenghuang_old_town.JPG/440px-Fenghuang_old_town.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fenghuang_old_town.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fenghuang_County" title="Fenghuang County">Fenghuang County</a>, an ancient town that harbors many architectural remains of Ming and Qing styles.</div></div></div>
<p>Since <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_China" title="Ancient China">ancient times</a>, Chinese culture has been heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>. For much of the country's dynastic era, opportunities for social advancement could be provided by high performance in the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Imperial_examination" title="Imperial examination">imperial examinations</a>, which have their origins in the Han dynasty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641"><a href="#cite_note-641">[610]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">literary emphasis</a> of the exams affected the general perception of cultural refinement in China, such as the belief that <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calligraphy" title="Chinese calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry" title="Classical Chinese poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_painting" title="Chinese painting">painting</a> were higher forms of art than dancing or drama. Chinese culture has long emphasized a sense of deep history and a largely inward-looking national perspective.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_642-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-642">[611]</a></sup> Examinations and a <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">culture of merit</a> remain greatly valued in China today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-643"><a href="#cite_note-643">[612]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty,_Nanjing_(flickr_1559896574).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg/220px-Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg/330px-Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg/440px-Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty%2C_Nanjing_%28flickr_1559896574%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yellow_Register_Archives_of_the_Ming_Dynasty,_Nanjing_(flickr_1559896574).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Moon_gate" title="Moon gate">Moon gate</a> in a Chinese garden.</div></div></div>
<p>The first leaders of the People's Republic of China were born into the traditional imperial order but were influenced by the <a href="/wiki/May_Fourth_Movement" title="May Fourth Movement">May Fourth Movement</a> and reformist ideals. They sought to change some traditional aspects of Chinese culture, such as rural land tenure, <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexism</a>, and the Confucian system of education, while preserving others, such as the family structure and culture of obedience to the state. Some observers see the period following the establishment of the PRC in 1949 as a continuation of traditional Chinese dynastic history, while others claim that the Communist Party's rule has damaged the foundations of Chinese culture, especially through political movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> of the 1960s, where many aspects of traditional culture were destroyed, having been denounced as "regressive and harmful" or "vestiges of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>". Many important aspects of traditional Chinese morals and culture, such as Confucianism, art, literature, and performing arts like <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcded_644-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcded-644">[613]</a></sup> were altered to conform to government policies and propaganda at the time. Access to foreign media remains heavily restricted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[614]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, the Chinese government has accepted numerous elements of traditional Chinese culture as being integral to Chinese society. With the rise of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_nationalism" title="Chinese nationalism">Chinese nationalism</a> and the end of the Cultural Revolution, various forms of traditional Chinese art, literature, music, film, fashion and architecture have seen a vigorous revival,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdef_646-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdef-646">[615]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeg_647-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeg-647">[616]</a></sup> and folk and variety art in particular have sparked interest nationally and even worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeh_648-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeh-648">[617]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_China" title="Tourism in China">Tourism in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_China" title="List of World Heritage Sites in China">List of World Heritage Sites in China</a></div>
<p>China received 55.7 million inbound international visitors in 2010,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abd_649-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abd-649">[618]</a></sup> and in 2012 was the third-most-visited country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-650"><a href="#cite_note-650">[619]</a></sup> It also experiences an enormous volume of <a href="/wiki/Domestic_tourism" title="Domestic tourism">domestic tourism</a>; an estimated 740 million Chinese holidaymakers traveled within the country in October 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-740MillionTourists_651-0"><a href="#cite_note-740MillionTourists-651">[620]</a></sup> China hosts the world's <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_by_country#Countries_with_major_concentrations_of_World_Heritage_Sites" title="World Heritage Sites by country">second-largest number</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_China" title="List of World Heritage Sites in China">56</a>) after Italy, and is one of the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">most popular tourist destinations</a> in the world (<a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Asia-Pacific" title="World Tourism rankings">first in the Asia-Pacific</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">Chinese literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/220px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/330px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/440px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The stories in <i><a href="/wiki/Journey_to_the_West" title="Journey to the West">Journey to the West</a></i> are common themes in <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Chinese literature is based on the literature of the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-652"><a href="#cite_note-652">[621]</a></sup> Concepts covered within the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_classic_texts" title="Chinese classic texts">Chinese classic texts</a> present a wide range of <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Schools_of_Thought" title="Hundred Schools of Thought">thoughts</a> and subjects including <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calendar" title="Chinese calendar">calendar</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_military_texts" title="List of Chinese military texts">military</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_astrology" title="Chinese astrology">astrology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_herbology" title="Chinese herbology">herbology</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_geography" title="Chinese geography">geography</a> and many others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-653"><a href="#cite_note-653">[622]</a></sup> Some of the most important early texts include the <i><a href="/wiki/I_Ching" title="I Ching">I Ching</a></i> and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classic_of_History" title="Classic of History">Shujing</a></i> within the <a href="/wiki/Four_Books_and_Five_Classics" title="Four Books and Five Classics">Four Books and Five Classics</a> which served as the Confucian authoritative books for the state-sponsored curriculum in dynastic era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-654"><a href="#cite_note-654">[623]</a></sup> Inherited from the <i><a href="/wiki/Classic_of_Poetry" title="Classic of Poetry">Classic of Poetry</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry" title="Classical Chinese poetry">classical Chinese poetry</a> developed to its <a href="/wiki/Floruit" title="Floruit">floruit</a> during the Tang dynasty. <a href="/wiki/Li_Bai" title="Li Bai">Li Bai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Du_Fu" title="Du Fu">Du Fu</a> opened the forking ways for the poetic circles through romanticism and realism respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-655"><a href="#cite_note-655">[624]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_historiography" title="Chinese historiography">Chinese historiography</a> began with the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shiji" title="Shiji">Shiji</a></i>, the overall scope of the historiographical tradition in China is termed the <a href="/wiki/Twenty-Four_Histories" title="Twenty-Four Histories">Twenty-Four Histories</a>, which set a vast stage for Chinese fictions along with <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">Chinese mythology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folklore" title="Chinese folklore">folklore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-656"><a href="#cite_note-656">[625]</a></sup> Pushed by a burgeoning citizen class in the Ming dynasty, Chinese classical fiction rose to a boom of the historical, town and <a href="/wiki/Gods_and_demons_fiction" title="Gods and demons fiction">gods and demons fictions</a> as represented by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_Great_Classical_Novels" title="Four Great Classical Novels">Four Great Classical Novels</a> which include <i><a href="/wiki/Water_Margin" title="Water Margin">Water Margin</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Romance of the Three Kingdoms">Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Journey_to_the_West" title="Journey to the West">Journey to the West</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dream_of_the_Red_Chamber" title="Dream of the Red Chamber">Dream of the Red Chamber</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-657"><a href="#cite_note-657">[626]</a></sup> Along with the <a href="/wiki/Wuxia" title="Wuxia">wuxia</a> fictions of <a href="/wiki/Jin_Yong" title="Jin Yong">Jin Yong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liang_Yusheng" title="Liang Yusheng">Liang Yusheng</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-658"><a href="#cite_note-658">[627]</a></sup> it remains an enduring source of popular culture in the <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_cultural_sphere" title="East Asian cultural sphere">East Asian cultural sphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-659"><a href="#cite_note-659">[628]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the wake of the <a href="/wiki/New_Culture_Movement" title="New Culture Movement">New Culture Movement</a> after the end of the Qing dynasty, Chinese literature embarked on a new era with <a href="/wiki/Written_vernacular_Chinese" title="Written vernacular Chinese">written vernacular Chinese</a> for ordinary citizens. <a href="/wiki/Hu_Shih" title="Hu Shih">Hu Shih</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lu_Xun" title="Lu Xun">Lu Xun</a> were pioneers in modern literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660"><a href="#cite_note-660">[629]</a></sup> Various literary genres, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Misty_poetry" title="Misty poetry">misty poetry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scar_literature" title="Scar literature">scar literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Young_adult_fiction" title="Young adult fiction">young adult fiction</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Xungen_movement" title="Xungen movement">xungen literature</a>, which is influenced by <a href="/wiki/Magic_realism" title="Magic realism">magic realism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-661"><a href="#cite_note-661">[630]</a></sup> emerged following the Cultural Revolution. <a href="/wiki/Mo_Yan" title="Mo Yan">Mo Yan</a>, a xungen literature author, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-662"><a href="#cite_note-662">[631]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuisines_of_China.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="902" data-file-width="1275" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Cuisines_of_China.png/220px-Cuisines_of_China.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Cuisines_of_China.png/330px-Cuisines_of_China.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Cuisines_of_China.png/440px-Cuisines_of_China.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cuisines_of_China.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing major regional cuisines of China</div></div></div>
<p>Chinese cuisine is highly diverse, drawing on several millennia of culinary history and geographical variety, in which the most influential are known as the "Eight Major Cuisines", including <a href="/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine" title="Sichuan cuisine">Sichuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine" title="Cantonese cuisine">Cantonese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiangsu_cuisine" title="Jiangsu cuisine">Jiangsu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shandong_cuisine" title="Shandong cuisine">Shandong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fujian_cuisine" title="Fujian cuisine">Fujian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunan_cuisine" title="Hunan cuisine">Hunan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anhui_cuisine" title="Anhui cuisine">Anhui</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine" title="Zhejiang cuisine">Zhejiang</a> cuisines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-663"><a href="#cite_note-663">[632]</a></sup> All of them are featured by the precise skills of shaping, heating, and flavoring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-664"><a href="#cite_note-664">[633]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (July 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Chinese cuisine is also known for its width of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cooking_techniques" title="Chinese cooking techniques">cooking methods</a> and ingredients,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665"><a href="#cite_note-665">[634]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Chinese_food_therapy" title="Chinese food therapy">food therapy</a> that is emphasized by <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">traditional Chinese medicine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-666"><a href="#cite_note-666">[635]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (July 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Generally, China's staple food is rice in the south, wheat-based breads and noodles in the north. The diet of the common people in pre-modern times was largely grain and simple vegetables, with meat reserved for special occasions. The bean products, such as <a href="/wiki/Tofu" title="Tofu">tofu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, remain as a popular source of protein.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667"><a href="#cite_note-667">[636]</a></sup> Pork is now the most popular meat in China, accounting for about three-fourths of the country's total meat consumption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-668"><a href="#cite_note-668">[637]</a></sup> While pork dominates the meat market, there is also the vegetarian <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cuisine" title="Buddhist cuisine">Buddhist cuisine</a> and the pork-free <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Islamic_cuisine" title="Chinese Islamic cuisine">Chinese Islamic cuisine</a>. Southern cuisine, due to the area's proximity to the ocean and milder climate, has a wide variety of seafood and vegetables; it differs in many respects from the wheat-based diets across dry northern China. Numerous offshoots of Chinese food, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Hong_Kong#Eastern_Styles" title="Cuisine of Hong Kong">Hong Kong cuisine</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Chinese_food" title="American Chinese food">American Chinese food</a>, have emerged in the nations that play host to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_diaspora" title="Chinese diaspora">Chinese diaspora</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_China" title="Music of China">Music of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/C-pop" title="C-pop">C-pop</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_opera" title="Chinese opera">Chinese opera</a></div>
<p>Chinese music covers a highly diverse range of music from traditional music to modern music. Chinese music dates back before the pre-imperial times. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_musical_instruments" title="Traditional Chinese musical instruments">Traditional Chinese musical instruments</a> were traditionally grouped into eight categories known as <i>bayin</i> (八音). Traditional Chinese opera is a form of musical theatre in China originating thousands of years and has regional style forms such as <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Beijing opera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cantonese_opera" title="Cantonese opera">Cantonese opera</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-669"><a href="#cite_note-669">[638]</a></sup> Chinese pop (C-Pop) includes <a href="/wiki/Mandopop" title="Mandopop">mandopop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cantopop" title="Cantopop">cantopop</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_rap" title="Chinese rap">Chinese rap</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_hip_hop" title="Chinese hip hop">Chinese hip hop</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_hip_hop" title="Hong Kong hip hop">Hong Kong hip hop</a> have become popular in contemporary times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-670"><a href="#cite_note-670">[639]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_China" title="Cinema of China">Cinema of China</a></div>
<p>Cinema was first introduced to China in 1896 and the first Chinese film, <i><a href="/wiki/Dingjun_Mountain_(film)" title="Dingjun Mountain (film)">Dingjun Mountain</a>,</i> was released in 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-671"><a href="#cite_note-671">[640]</a></sup> China has the largest number of movie screens in the world since 2016,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hr_672-0"><a href="#cite_note-hr-672">[641]</a></sup> China became the largest cinema market in the world in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-673"><a href="#cite_note-673">[642]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-674"><a href="#cite_note-674">[643]</a></sup> The top 3 <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_China" title="List of highest-grossing films in China">highest-grossing films in China</a> currently are <i><a href="/wiki/Wolf_Warrior_2" title="Wolf Warrior 2">Wolf Warrior 2</a></i> (2017)<i>, <a href="/wiki/Ne_Zha_(2019_film)" title="Ne Zha (2019 film)">Ne Zha</a></i> (2019), and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wandering_Earth" title="The Wandering Earth">The Wandering Earth</a></i> (2019).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-675"><a href="#cite_note-675">[644]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion">Fashion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fashion_in_China" title="Fashion in China">Fashion in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hanfu" title="Hanfu">Hanfu</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hanfu" title="Hanfu">Hanfu</a> is the historical clothing of the Han people in China. The <a href="/wiki/Cheongsam" title="Cheongsam">qipao</a> or cheongsam is a popular Chinese female dress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-676"><a href="#cite_note-676">[645]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hanfu_movement" title="Hanfu movement">hanfu movement</a> has been popular in contemporary times and seeks to revitalize Hanfu clothing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-677"><a href="#cite_note-677">[646]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_China" title="Sport in China">Sport in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_Olympics" title="China at the Olympics">China at the Olympics</a></div>
<p>China has one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Sport in the People's Republic of China">oldest sporting cultures</a> in the world. There is evidence that <a href="/wiki/Archery" title="Archery">archery</a> (<i>shèjiàn</i>) was practiced during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Zhou_dynasty" title="Western Zhou dynasty">Western Zhou dynasty</a>. Swordplay (<i>jiànshù</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Cuju" title="Cuju">cuju</a>, a sport loosely related to <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-678"><a href="#cite_note-678">[647]</a></sup> date back to China's early dynasties as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-679"><a href="#cite_note-679">[648]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FloorGoban.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1101" data-file-width="1137" decoding="async" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/FloorGoban.JPG/200px-FloorGoban.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/FloorGoban.JPG/300px-FloorGoban.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/FloorGoban.JPG/400px-FloorGoban.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FloorGoban.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Go_(game)" title="Go (game)">Go</a> is an abstract strategy board game for two players, in which the aim is to surround more territory than the opponent and was invented in China more than 2,500 years ago.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Physical_fitness" title="Physical fitness">Physical fitness</a> is widely emphasized in Chinese culture, with morning exercises such as <a href="/wiki/Qigong" title="Qigong">qigong</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%27ai_chi_ch%27uan" title="T'ai chi ch'uan">t'ai chi ch'uan</a> widely practiced,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-680"><a href="#cite_note-680">[649]</a></sup> and commercial <a href="/wiki/Gym" title="Gym">gyms</a> and private fitness clubs are gaining popularity across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-681"><a href="#cite_note-681">[650]</a></sup> Basketball is currently the most popular spectator sport in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-682"><a href="#cite_note-682">[651]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Basketball_Association" title="Chinese Basketball Association">Chinese Basketball Association</a> and the American <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a> have a huge following among the people, with native or ethnic Chinese players such as <a href="/wiki/Yao_Ming" title="Yao Ming">Yao Ming</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yi_Jianlian" title="Yi Jianlian">Yi Jianlian</a> held in high esteem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beech2003_683-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beech2003-683">[652]</a></sup> China's professional football league, now known as <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Super_League" title="Chinese Super League">Chinese Super League</a>, was established in 1994, it is the largest football market in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-684"><a href="#cite_note-684">[653]</a></sup> Other popular sports in the country include <a href="/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts" title="Chinese martial arts">martial arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">snooker</a>. <a href="/wiki/Board_game" title="Board game">Board games</a> such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Go_(board_game)" title="Go (board game)">go</a> (known as <i>wéiqí</i> in Chinese), <a href="/wiki/Xiangqi" title="Xiangqi">xiangqi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahjong" title="Mahjong">mahjong</a>, and more recently <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, are also played at a professional level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-685"><a href="#cite_note-685">[654]</a></sup> In addition, China is home to a huge number of <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">cyclists</a>, with an estimated 470 million bicycles as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470MBikes_509-1"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-509">[481]</a></sup> Many more traditional sports, such as <a href="/wiki/Dragon_boat" title="Dragon boat">dragon boat</a> racing, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_wrestling" title="Mongolian wrestling">Mongolian-style wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> are also popular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcden_686-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcden-686">[655]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_Olympics" title="China at the Olympics">participated in the Olympic Games</a> since 1932, although it has only participated as the PRC <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics" title="China at the 1952 Summer Olympics">since 1952</a>. China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing, where its athletes received 48 gold medals – <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics_medal_table" title="2008 Summer Olympics medal table">the highest number of gold medals</a> of any participating nation that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeo_687-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeo-687">[656]</a></sup> China also won the most medals of any nation at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Paralympics" title="2012 Summer Paralympics">2012 Summer Paralympics</a>, with 231 overall, including 95 gold medals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-688"><a href="#cite_note-688">[657]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-689"><a href="#cite_note-689">[658]</a></sup> In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a> in Guangdong, China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2011_Summer_Universiade" title="2011 Summer Universiade">2011 Summer Universiade</a>. China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2013_East_Asian_Games" title="2013 East Asian Games">2013 East Asian Games</a> in Tianjin and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2014 Summer Youth Olympics">2014 Summer Youth Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>; the first country to host both regular and Youth Olympics. Beijing and its nearby city <a href="/wiki/Zhangjiakou" title="Zhangjiakou">Zhangjiakou</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebei_province" title="Hebei province">Hebei province</a> collaboratively hosted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2022_Olympic_Winter_Games" title="2022 Olympic Winter Games">2022 Olympic Winter Games</a>, making Beijing the first dual olympic city in the world by holding both the Summer Olympics and the Winter Olympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-690"><a href="#cite_note-690">[659]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-691"><a href="#cite_note-691">[660]</a></sup>
</p>
