<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Chinese and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> are the official languages in <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong SAR</a> only. Chinese and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> are the official languages in <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau SAR</a> only.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><div><ul><li>In the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong SAR</a> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">Traditional Chinese characters</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_alphabet" title="English alphabet">English alphabet</a> are used,</li><li>In the <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau SAR</a> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">Traditional Chinese characters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_orthography" title="Portuguese orthography">Portuguese orthography</a> are used,</li><li>In <a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a> the <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_script" title="Mongolian script">Mongolian script</a> is used alongside simplified Chinese,</li><li>In the <a href="/wiki/Tibet_Autonomous_Region" title="Tibet Autonomous Region">Tibet Autonomous Region</a> the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_script" title="Tibetan script">Tibetan script</a> is used alongside simplified Chinese,</li><li>In <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> the <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_Arabic_alphabet" title="Uyghur Arabic alphabet">Uyghur Arabic alphabet</a> is used alongside simplified Chinese,</li><li>In <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wenshan_Zhuang_and_Miao_Autonomous_Prefecture" title="Wenshan Zhuang and Miao Autonomous Prefecture">Wenshan Prefecture</a> the <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> is used alongside simplified Chinese,</li><li>In the <a href="/wiki/Yanbian_Korean_Autonomous_Prefecture" title="Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture">Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chos%C5%8Fn%27g%C5%ADl" title="Chosŏn'gŭl">Chosŏn'gŭl</a> is used alongside simplified Chinese.</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">PRC President</a> is head of state, it is a largely <a href="/wiki/Figurehead" title="Figurehead">ceremonial office</a> with limited power under <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP General Secretary</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including both state and party's central military chairs.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The area given is the official United Nations figure for <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">the mainland</a> and excludes <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_Stat_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Stat-10">[5]</a></sup> It also excludes the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Karakoram_Tract" title="Trans-Karakoram Tract">Trans-Karakoram Tract</a> (5,180 km<sup>2</sup> (2,000 sq mi)), <a href="/wiki/Aksai_Chin" title="Aksai Chin">Aksai Chin</a> (38,000 km<sup>2</sup> (15,000 sq mi)) and other territories in dispute with India. The total area of China is listed as 9,572,900 km<sup>2</sup> (3,696,100 sq mi) by the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[6]</a></sup> For further information, see <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China">Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This figure was calculated using data from the CIA World Factbook.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-14">[8]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><div><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_dollar" title="Hong Kong dollar">Hong Kong dollar</a> used in Hong Kong and Macau</li><li><a href="/wiki/Macanese_pataca" title="Macanese pataca">Macanese pataca</a> used in Macau only.</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hans">中国</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Zhōngguó</span></i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hans">中华人民共和国</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó</span></i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> have the two largest populations among countries worldwide, significantly ahead of all other countries. China's population is slightly ahead of India's, with both countries having populations in excess of 1.4 billion as of 2021. The next-most-populous country is the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, with a population of over 330 million as of 2021.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China officially uses only one universal time zone called "<a href="/wiki/Time_in_China" title="Time in China">Beijing Time</a>", despite its huge territorial expanse.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China borders fourteen countries by land: <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> to the northeast; <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a> to the southwest; and <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> to the south. China's border with Pakistan is disputed by India, which claims the entire <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> region as its territory.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-TaiwanClaim-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-TaiwanClaim_28-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-TaiwanClaim_28-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">China claims the <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition"><i>de facto</i> state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, which it does not control, as its disputed 23rd province, i.e. <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China">Taiwan Province</a>. See <a href="#Administrative_divisions">§ Administrative divisions</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Taiwan (officially the Republic of China) controls <a href="/wiki/Kinmen" title="Kinmen">Kinmen Island</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Matsu_Islands" title="Matsu Islands">Matsu Islands</a>, which are located in the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Strait" title="Taiwan Strait">Taiwan Strait</a>. Kinmen in particular is located very nearby to China's <a href="/wiki/Fujian" title="Fujian">Fujian Province</a>, lying roughly 10 km (6.2 mi) east of the city of <a href="/wiki/Xiamen" title="Xiamen">Xiamen</a>, Fujian.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The total area ranking relative to the United States depends on the measurement of the total areas of both countries. See <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">List of countries and dependencies by area</a> for more information.

The following two primary sources (non-mirrored) represent the range (min./max.) of estimates of China's and the United States' total areas.

Both sources (1) <i>exclude</i> Taiwan from the area of China; (2) <i>exclude</i> China's coastal and territorial waters.

However, the CIA World Factbook <i>includes</i> the United States coastal and territorial waters, while Encyclopædia Britannica <i>excludes</i> the United States coastal and territorial waters.

<div><ol><li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i> lists China as world's third-largest country (after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>) with a total area of 9,572,900 km<sup>2</sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[15]</a></sup> and the United States as fourth-largest at 9,525,067 km<sup>2</sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-United_States_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-United_States-31">[16]</a></sup></li><li>The <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> lists China as fourth-largest country (after Russia, Canada and the United States) with a total area of 9,596,960 km<sup>2</sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[17]</a></sup> and the United States as the third-largest at 9,833,517 km<sup>2</sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[18]</a></sup></li></ol></div>
<p>Notably, the Encyclopædia Britannica specifies the United States' area (excluding coastal and territorial waters) as 9,525,067 km<sup>2</sup>, which is less than either source's figure given for China's area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-United_States_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-United_States-31">[16]</a></sup> Therefore, while it can be determined that China has a larger area excluding coastal and territorial waters, it is unclear which country has a larger area including coastal and territorial waters.
</p>
<hr/>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Statistics_Division" title="United Nations Statistics Division">United Nations Statistics Division</a>'s figure for the United States is 9,833,517 km<sup>2</sup> (3,796,742 sq mi) and China is 9,596,961 km<sup>2</sup> (3,705,407 sq mi). These closely match the CIA World Factbook figures and similarly <i>include</i> coastal and territorial waters for the United States, but <i>exclude</i> coastal and territorial waters for China.
</p>
<hr/>
<p>Further explanation of disputed ranking: The dispute about which is the world's third-largest country arose from the inclusion of coastal and territorial waters for the United States. This discrepancy was deduced from comparing the CIA World Factbook and its previous iterations<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31_Years_of_CIA_World_Factbook_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-31_Years_of_CIA_World_Factbook-34">[19]</a></sup> against the information for United States in <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>, particularly its footnote section.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-United_States_31-2"><a href="#cite_note-United_States-31">[16]</a></sup> In sum, according to older versions of the CIA World Factbook (from 1982 to 1996), the U.S. was listed as the world's fourth-largest country (after Russia, Canada, and China) with a total area of 9,372,610 km<sup>2</sup> (3,618,780 sq mi). However, in the 1997 edition, the U.S. added coastal waters to its total area (increasing it to 9,629,091 km<sup>2</sup> (3,717,813 sq mi)). And then again in 2007, U.S. added territorial water to its total area (increasing it to 9,833,517 km<sup>2</sup> (3,796,742 sq mi)). During this time, China's total area remained unchanged. In other words, <i>no</i> coastal or territorial water area was added to China's total area figure. The United States has a coastal water area of 109,362 km<sup>2</sup> (42,225 sq mi), and a territorial water area of 195,213 km<sup>2</sup> (75,372 sq mi), for a total of 304,575 km<sup>2</sup> (117,597 sq mi) of additional water space. This is larger than entire countries like Italy, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Adding this figure to the U.S. will boost it over China in ranking since China's coastal and territorial water figures are currently unknown (no official publication) and thus cannot be added into China's total area figure.
</p>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The island of <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Landing_Operation_on_Hainan_Island" title="Landing Operation on Hainan Island">taken</a> on 1 May 1950 while the <a href="/wiki/Tibet_(1912%E2%80%931951)" title="Tibet (1912–1951)">unrecognized polity</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> was <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Tibet_by_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Annexation of Tibet by the People's Republic of China">annexed</a> on 23 May 1951.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The KMT solely governed the island until its transition to democracy in 1996.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"...<span class="nowrap"> </span>Next vnto this, is found the great China, whose kyng is thought to bee the greatest prince in the worlde, and is named Santoa Raia".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[23]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"...<span class="nowrap"> </span>The Very Great Kingdom of China".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[24]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">...<span class="nowrap"> </span>O Grande Reino da China<span class="nowrap"> </span>...</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[25]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although this is the present meaning of <i><span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">guó</i></span></i>, in <a href="/wiki/Old_Chinese" title="Old Chinese">Old Chinese</a> (when its pronunciation was something like <span class="nowrap">/*qʷˤək/</span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bs_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-bs-51">[31]</a></sup> it meant the walled city of the Chinese and the areas they could control from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-52">[32]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Its earliest extant use is on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ritual_bronze" title="Ritual bronze">ritual bronze</a> vessel <a href="/wiki/He_zun" title="He zun">He zun</a>, where it apparently refers to only the <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang</a>'s immediate demesne conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[33]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Its meaning "Zhou's royal demesne" is attested from the 6th-century BC <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classic_of_History" title="Classic of History">Classic of History</a>, which states "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian_(god)" title="Tian (god)">Huangtian</a> bestowed the lands and the peoples of the central state to the ancestors" (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">皇天既付中國民越厥疆土于先王</span></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[34]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Owing to Qin Shi Huang's earlier policy involving the "<a href="/wiki/Burning_of_books_and_burying_of_scholars" title="Burning of books and burying of scholars">burning of books and burying of scholars</a>", the destruction of the confiscated copies at Xianyang was an event similar to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Destruction_of_the_Library_of_Alexandria" title="Destruction of the Library of Alexandria">destructions</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Alexandria" title="Library of Alexandria">Library of Alexandria</a> in the west. Even those texts that did survive had to be painstakingly reconstructed from memory, luck, or forgery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[60]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Old_Texts" title="Old Texts">Old Texts</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_Classics" title="Five Classics">Five Classics</a> were said to have been found hidden in a wall at the Kong residence in <a href="/wiki/Qufu" title="Qufu">Qufu</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mei_Ze" title="Mei Ze">Mei Ze</a>'s "rediscovered" edition of the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Documents" title="Book of Documents">Book of Documents</a> was <a href="/wiki/Yan_Ruoqu" title="Yan Ruoqu">only shown to be a forgery in the Qing dynasty</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-223">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China is larger than Canada and the United States in terms of land area.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-224"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-224">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>, the total area of the United States, at 9,522,055 km<sup>2</sup> (3,676,486 sq mi), is slightly smaller than that of China. Meanwhile, the <i>CIA World Factbook</i> states that China's total area was greater than that of the United States until the coastal waters of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> was added to the United States' total area in 1996. From 1989 through 1996, the total area of US was listed as 9,372,610 km<sup>2</sup> (3,618,780 sq mi) (land area plus inland water only). The listed total area changed to 9,629,091 km<sup>2</sup> (3,717,813 sq mi) in 1997 (with the Great Lakes areas and the coastal waters added), to 9,631,418 km<sup>2</sup> (3,718,711 sq mi) in 2004, to 9,631,420 km<sup>2</sup> (3,718,710 sq mi) in 2006, and to 9,826,630 km<sup>2</sup> (3,794,080 sq mi) in 2007 (territorial waters added).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-227"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-227">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China's border with Pakistan and part of its border with India falls in the disputed region of <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a>. The area under Pakistani administration is claimed by India, while the area under Indian administration is claimed by Pakistan.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-464"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-464">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Tsung-Dao_Lee" title="Tsung-Dao Lee">Tsung-Dao Lee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Physics_1957_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Physics_1957-458">[431]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chen_Ning_Yang" title="Chen Ning Yang">Chen Ning Yang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Physics_1957_458-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Physics_1957-458">[431]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_C._Tsui" title="Daniel C. Tsui">Daniel C. Tsui</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[432]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Charles_K._Kao" title="Charles K. Kao">Charles K. Kao</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[433]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yuan_T._Lee" title="Yuan T. Lee">Yuan T. Lee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[434]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tu_Youyou" title="Tu Youyou">Tu Youyou</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[435]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shing-Tung_Yau" title="Shing-Tung Yau">Shing-Tung Yau</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[436]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-605"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-605">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The national life expectancy at birth rose from about 31 years in 1949 to 75 years in 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[573]</a></sup> and infant mortality decreased from 300 per thousand in the 1950s to around 33 per thousand in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcu_604-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcu-604">[574]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-CIA-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_14-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_14-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_14-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/china" rel="nofollow">"China"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i> (2022 ed.). <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/china" rel="nofollow">"China"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i> (2022 ed.). <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-2020_census-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-2020_census_17-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2020_census_17-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/202105/t20210510_1817187.html" rel="nofollow">"Communiqué of the Seventh National Population Census (No. 2)"</a>. <i>National Bureau of Statistics of China</i>. 11 May 2021. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210511104840/http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/202105/t20210510_1817187.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 May</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=National+Bureau+of+Statistics+of+China&amp;rft.atitle=Communiqu%C3%A9+of+the+Seventh+National+Population+Census+%28No.+2%29&amp;rft.date=2021-05-11&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.stats.gov.cn%2Fenglish%2FPressRelease%2F202105%2Ft20210510_1817187.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EN.POP.DNST" rel="nofollow">"Population density (people per km<sup>2</sup> of land area)"</a>. IMF<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 May</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Population+density+%28people+per+km%3Csup%3E2%3C%2Fsup%3E+of+land+area%29&amp;rft.pub=IMF&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdata.worldbank.org%2Findicator%2FEN.POP.DNST&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-158">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/regional-integration/brief/belt-and-road-initiative" rel="nofollow">"Belt and Road Initiative"</a>. <li id="cite_note-193"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-193">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=OeqjKhDml6wC&amp;pg=PA208" rel="nofollow"><i>Conservation Biology: Voices from the Tropics</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWei2014">Wei, Yuwa (2014). <li id="cite_note-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-239">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFHernández2017">Hernández, Javier C. <li id="cite_note-242"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-242">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/in_depth/china_politics/government/html/7.stm" rel="nofollow">"How China is Ruled: National People's Congress"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-ReferenceA-243"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_243-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The landmark study of military generations and factions is William Whitson's <i>The Chinese High Command,</i> Praeger, 1973</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-294"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-294">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFravel2008">Fravel, M. <li id="cite_note-302"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-302">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFKingPanRoberts2013">King, Gary; Pan, Jennifer; Roberts, Margaret E. <li id="cite_note-SIPRI2014-328"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-SIPRI2014_328-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-SIPRI2014_328-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFPerlo-Freeman2014">Perlo-Freeman, Sam (March 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150209162900/http://www.sipri.org/media/newsletter/essay/perlo-freeman-mar-2013" rel="nofollow">"Mar. 2014: Deciphering China's latest defence budget figures"</a>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SIPRI" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-362"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-362">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2020/10/15/can-chinas-reported-growth-be-trusted" rel="nofollow">"Can China's reported growth be trusted?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>. 15 October 2020. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0013-0613" rel="nofollow">0013-0613</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-415"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-415">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"RMB Settlement", Kasikorn Research Center, Bangkok, 8 February 2011</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-418"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-418">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20171010151157/http://ministers.treasury.gov.au/DisplayDocs.aspx?doc=pressreleases%2F2013%2F044.htm&amp;pageID=&amp;min=wms&amp;Year=&amp;DocType=0" rel="nofollow">"China and Australia Announce Direct Currency Trading"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Treasury_(Australia)" title="Department of the Treasury (Australia)">Department of the Treasury (Australia)</a>. <li id="cite_note-420"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-420">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9579f608-356e-11e3-b539-00144feab7de.html" rel="nofollow">"Chancellor George Osborne cements London as renminbi hub"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i>. <q>The two countries agreed to allow direct renminbi-sterling trading in Shanghai and offshore, making the pound the fourth currency to trade directly against the renminbi, while Chinese banks will be permitted to set up branches in London.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Financial+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Chancellor+George+Osborne+cements+London+as+renminbi+hub&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fintl%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F9579f608-356e-11e3-b539-00144feab7de.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-421"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-421">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://bankofcanada.ca/2014/11/bofc-announces-signing-reciprocal-bilateral-swap" rel="nofollow">"Bank of Canada announces signing of reciprocal 3-year Canadian dollar/renminbi bilateral swap arrangement"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Canada" title="Bank of Canada">Bank of Canada</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>As part of the initiative announced today by the Government of Canada to promote increased trade and investment between Canada and China, as well as to support domestic financial stability should market conditions warrant, Governor Stephen S. Poloz and Governor Zhou Xiaochuan of the People's Bank of China have signed an agreement establishing a reciprocal 3-year, Canadian dollar (Can$)/renminbi (RMB) currency swap line.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Bank+of+Canada+announces+signing+of+reciprocal+3-year+Canadian+dollar%2Frenminbi+bilateral+swap+arrangement&amp;rft.pub=Bank+of+Canada&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbankofcanada.ca%2F2014%2F11%2Fbofc-announces-signing-reciprocal-bilateral-swap&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Water_Scarcity_in_China-523"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Water_Scarcity_in_China_523-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFHook2013">Hook, Leslie (14 May 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/7d6f69ea-bc73-11e2-b344-00144feab7de.html" rel="nofollow">"China: High and dry: Water shortages put a brake on economic growth"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 May</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Financial+Times&amp;rft.atitle=China%3A+High+and+dry%3A+Water+shortages+put+a+brake+on+economic+growth&amp;rft.date=2013-05-14&amp;rft.aulast=Hook&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fintl%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F7d6f69ea-bc73-11e2-b344-00144feab7de.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-524"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-524">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160304112745/http://www.wssinfo.org/fileadmin/user_upload/resources/JMP-Update-report-2015_English.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Website of the Joint Monitoring Program for Water Supply and Sanitation"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. JMP (WHO and UNICEF). <li id="cite_note-Whyte-536"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Whyte_536-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWhyteWangCai2015">Whyte, Martin K.; <li id="cite_note-537"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-537">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" <li id="cite_note-538"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-538">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFParry2005">Parry, Simon (9 January 2005). <span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/1480778/Shortage-of-girls-forces-China-to-criminalise-selective-abortion.html" rel="nofollow">"Shortage of girls forces China to criminalize selective abortion"</a></span>. <i>The Daily Telegraph</i>. London. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/1480778/Shortage-of-girls-forces-China-to-criminalise-selective-abortion.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 10 January 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-langlaw-549"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-langlaw_549-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130724204951/http://www.gov.cn/english/laws/2005-09/19/content_64906.htm" rel="nofollow">"Law of the People's Republic of China on the Standard Spoken and Written Chinese Language (Order of the President No.37)"</a>. <li id="cite_note-auto1-576"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto1_576-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto1_576-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://en.moe.gov.cn/features/2021TwoSessions/Reports/202103/t20210323_522026.html" rel="nofollow">"Major educational achievements in China in 2020 – Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China"</a>. <i>en.moe.gov.cn</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-614"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-614">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFNovel_Coronavirus_Pneumonia_Emergency_Response_Epidemiology_Team2020">Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia Emergency Response Epidemiology Team (17 February 2020). [The "Epidemiological Characteristics of an Outbreak of 2019 Novel Coronavirus Diseases (COVID-19) in China"]. <i>Zhonghua Liu Xing Bing Xue Za Zhi = Zhonghua Liuxingbingxue Zazhi</i> <bdi lang="zh">中华流行病学杂志</bdi> (in Chinese). <b>41</b> (2): 145–151. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.3760%2Fcma.j.issn.0254-6450.2020.02.003" rel="nofollow">10.3760/cma.j.issn.0254-6450.2020.02.003</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32064853" rel="nofollow">32064853</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:211133882" rel="nofollow">211133882</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Zhonghua+Liu+Xing+Bing+Xue+Za+Zhi+%3D+Zhonghua+Liuxingbingxue+Zazhi&amp;rft.atitle=Epidemiological+Characteristics+of+an+Outbreak+of+2019+Novel+Coronavirus+Diseases+%28COVID-19%29+in+China&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=145-151&amp;rft.date=2020-02-17&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A211133882%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F32064853&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.3760%2Fcma.j.issn.0254-6450.2020.02.003&amp;rft.au=Novel+Coronavirus+Pneumonia+Emergency+Response+Epidemiology+Team&amp;rft_id=The&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span> <span class="cs1-visible-error citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">{{<a href="/wiki/Template:Cite_journal" title="Template:Cite journal">cite journal</a>}}</code>: </span><span class="cs1-visible-error citation-comment">Check <code class="cs1-code">|url=</code> value (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#bad_url" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-map3-620"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-map3_620-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation map cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFGao_高1995">Gao 高, Wende 文德, ed. </li>
<li id="cite_note-map4-621"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-map4_621-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation map cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFYin_殷Li_李Guo_郭1991">Yin 殷, Haishan 海山; Li 李, Yaozong 耀宗; Guo 郭, Jie 洁, eds. (1991). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170427135713/http://refbook.img.cnki.net/CRFDPIC/r200606014/r200606014.0652.288333.jpg" rel="nofollow">"Religions in China"</a>  (Map).  <bdi lang="zh">中国少数民族艺术词典</bdi> [<i>Chinese Minorities' Arts Dictionary</i>] (in Chinese). Beijing: National Publishing House (民族出版社). </li>
<li id="cite_note-622"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-622">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDillon2001">Dillon, Michael (2001). <i>Religious Minorities and China</i>. Minority Rights Group International.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religious+Minorities+and+China&amp;rft.pub=Minority+Rights+Group+International&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.aulast=Dillon&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-BuangChew2014-623"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BuangChew2014_623-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBuangChew2014">Buang, Sa'eda; Chew, Phyllis Ghim-Lian (9 May 2014). <i>Muslim Education in the 21st Century: Asian Perspectives</i>. <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a>. p. 75. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-81500-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-81500-6"><bdi>978-1-317-81500-6</bdi></a>. <q>Subsequently, a new China was found on the basis of Communist ideology, i.e. atheism. Within the framework of this ideology, religion was treated as a 'contorted' world-view and people believed that religion would necessarily disappear at the end, along with the development of human society. A series of anti-religious campaigns was implemented by the Chinese Communist Party from the early 1950s to the late 1970s. As a result, in nearly 30 years between the beginning of the 1950s and the end of the 1970s, mosques (as well as churches and Chinese temples) were shut down and Imams involved in forced 're-education'.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Muslim+Education+in+the+21st+Century%3A+Asian+Perspectives&amp;rft.pages=75&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2014-05-09&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-81500-6&amp;rft.aulast=Buang&amp;rft.aufirst=Sa%27eda&amp;rft.au=Chew%2C+Phyllis+Ghim-Lian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-624"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-624">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-script"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150812102019/http://www.sara.gov.cn/jqgk/zs/index.htm" rel="nofollow"><bdi lang="zh">国家宗教事务局</bdi></a>. National Religious Affairs Administration. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.sara.gov.cn/jqgk/zs/index.htm" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 12 August 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 August</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%E5%9B%BD%E5%AE%B6%E5%AE%97%E6%95%99%E4%BA%8B%E5%8A%A1%E5%B1%80&amp;rft.pub=National+Religious+Affairs+Administration&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sara.gov.cn%2Fjqgk%2Fzs%2Findex.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-625"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-625">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Constitution of the People's Republic of China</i>. Chapter 2, Article 36.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Yao2011-626"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Yao2011_626-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Yao2011_626-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFYao2010"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yao_Xinzhong" title="Yao Xinzhong">Yao, Xinzhong</a> (2010). <i>Chinese Religion: A Contextual Approach</i>. London: A&amp;C Black. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84706-475-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84706-475-2"><bdi>978-1-84706-475-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Chinese+Religion%3A+A+Contextual+Approach&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=A%26C+Black&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84706-475-2&amp;rft.aulast=Yao&amp;rft.aufirst=Xinzhong&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span> pp. 9–11.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-627"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-627">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMiller2006">Miller, James (2006). <i>Chinese Religions in Contemporary Societies</i>. ABC-CLIO. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-626-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-626-8"><bdi>978-1-85109-626-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Chinese+Religions+in+Contemporary+Societies&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85109-626-8&amp;rft.aulast=Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span> <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=S4vg8BQrqA4C&amp;pg=PA57" rel="nofollow">p. 57</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-628"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-628">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tam Wai Lun, "Local Religion in Contemporary China", in <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFXie2006">Xie, Zhibin (2006). <i>Religious Diversity and Public Religion in China</i>. <li id="cite_note-629"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-629">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFTeiser1996">Teiser, Stephen F. <li id="cite_note-Laliberte2011-630"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Laliberte2011_630-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a leaders of Shanxi have gone further with their promotion of worship of the Yellow Emperor (<span lang="zh-Hant">黃帝</span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Huáng Dì</span></i>)".</span>

<li id="cite_note-640"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-640">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?CID=31&amp;ID_SITE=881&amp;l=EN" rel="nofollow">"Temple of Heaven: an Imperial Sacrificial Altar in Beijing"</a>. <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-689"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-689">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/story/2012/09/9/china-dominates-medals-us-falls-short-at-paralympics/57719222/1" rel="nofollow">"China dominates medals; U.S. falls short at Paralympics"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i>. 9 September 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">19 June</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=USA+Today&amp;rft.atitle=China+dominates+medals%3B+U.S.+falls+short+at+Paralympics&amp;rft.date=2012-09-09&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usatoday.com%2Fsports%2Folympics%2Fstory%2F2012%2F09%2F9%2Fchina-dominates-medals-us-falls-short-at-paralympics%2F57719222%2F1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-690"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-690">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://olympics.com/en/news/100-days-to-go-beijing-worlds-first-dual-olympic-city" rel="nofollow">"Beijing: The world's first dual Olympic city"</a>. olympics.com<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 February</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Beijing%3A+The+world%27s+first+dual+Olympic+city&amp;rft.pub=olympics.com&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Folympics.com%2Fen%2Fnews%2F100-days-to-go-beijing-worlds-first-dual-olympic-city&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-691"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-691">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.olympic.org/beijing-2022" rel="nofollow">"Beijing 2022 Winter Games Olympics – results &amp; video highlights"</a>. International Olympic Committee. 23 February 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 February</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Beijing+2022+Winter+Games+Olympics+%E2%80%93+results+%26+video+highlights&amp;rft.pub=International+Olympic+Committee&amp;rft.date=2018-02-23&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.olympic.org%2Fbeijing-2022&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></span>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/Bibliography_of_Chinese_history" title="Bibliography of Chinese history">Bibliography of Chinese history</a>.</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1054258005">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul li{list-style:none}@media(max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{padding-left:1.6em;text-indent:-1.6em}}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="refbegin refbegin-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 40em">
<ul><li>Farah, Paolo (2006). "Five Years of China's WTO Membership: EU and US Perspectives on China's Compliance with Transparency Commitments and the Transitional Review Mechanism". <i>Legal Issues of Economic Integration</i>. Kluwer Law International. Volume 33, Number 3. pp. 263–304. <a class="external text" href="https://ssrn.com/abstract=916768" rel="nofollow">Abstract</a>.</li>
<li>Heilig, Gerhard K. (2006/2007). <i><a class="external text" href="http://www.china-profile.com/bib/bib_start.htm" rel="nofollow">China Bibliography – Online</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20151105234238/http://www.china-profile.com/bib/bib_start.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 5 November 2015 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>.</i> China-Profile.com.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Martin_Jacques" title="Martin Jacques">Jacques, Martin</a> (2009).<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/When_China_Rules_the_World:_The_End_of_the_Western_World_and_the_Birth_of_a_New_Global_Order" title="When China Rules the World: The End of the Western World and the Birth of a New Global Order">When China Rules the World: The End of the Western World and the Birth of a New Global Order</a></i>. Penguin Books. Rev. ed. (28 August 2012). <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59420-185-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59420-185-1">978-1-59420-185-1</a></li>
<li>Jaffe, Amy Myers, "Green Giant: Renewable Energy and Chinese Power", <i><a href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs" title="Foreign Affairs">Foreign Affairs</a></i>, vol. 97, no. 2 (March / April 2018), pp. 83–93.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ian_Denis_Johnson" title="Ian Denis Johnson">Johnson, Ian</a>, "What Holds China Together?", <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Review_of_Books" title="The New York Review of Books">The New York Review of Books</a></i>, vol. LXVI, no. 14 (26 September 2019), pp. 14, 16, 18. "The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manchus" title="Manchus">Manchus</a><span class="nowrap"> </span>... had [in 1644] conquered the last ethnic Chinese empire, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ming_empire" title="Ming empire">Ming</a> [and established Imperial China's last dynasty, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing" title="Qing">Qing</a>]<span class="nowrap"> </span>... The Manchus expanded the empire's borders northward to include all of <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, and westward to <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>." [p. 16.] "China's rulers have no faith that anything but force can keep this sprawling country intact." [p. 18.]</li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLagerwey2010">Lagerwey, John (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WAOOzQi0dCkC" rel="nofollow"><i>China: A Religious State</i></a>. Hong Kong: University of Hong Kong Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-988-8028-04-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-988-8028-04-7"><bdi>978-988-8028-04-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=China%3A+A+Religious+State&amp;rft.place=Hong+Kong&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hong+Kong+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-988-8028-04-7&amp;rft.aulast=Lagerwey&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWAOOzQi0dCkC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMeng2011">Meng, Fanhua (2011). <i>Phenomenon of Chinese Culture at the Turn of the 21st century</i>. Singapore: Silkroad Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-981-4332-35-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-981-4332-35-4"><bdi>978-981-4332-35-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Phenomenon+of+Chinese+Culture+at+the+Turn+of+the+21st+century&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Silkroad+Press&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-981-4332-35-4&amp;rft.aulast=Meng&amp;rft.aufirst=Fanhua&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSang_Ye2006">Sang Ye (2006). <i>China Candid: The People on the People's Republic</i>. <a href="/wiki/University_of_California_Press" title="University of California Press">University of California Press</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-520-24514-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-520-24514-3"><bdi>978-0-520-24514-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=China+Candid%3A+The+People+on+the+People%27s+Republic&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-520-24514-3&amp;rft.au=Sang+Ye&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSelden1979">Selden, Mark (1979). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/peoplesrepublico0000unse" rel="nofollow"><i>The People's Republic of China: Documentary History of Revolutionary Change</i></a></span>. New York: Monthly Review Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85345-532-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85345-532-5"><bdi>978-0-85345-532-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+People%27s+Republic+of+China%3A+Documentary+History+of+Revolutionary+Change&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Monthly+Review+Press&amp;rft.date=1979&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-85345-532-5&amp;rft.aulast=Selden&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fpeoplesrepublico0000unse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFShambaugh2008">Shambaugh, David L. (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=aMpj-MboMR4C" rel="nofollow"><i>China's Communist Party: Atrophy and Adaptation</i></a>. Washington, DC; Berkeley, CA: University of California Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-520-25492-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-520-25492-3"><bdi>978-0-520-25492-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=China%27s+Communist+Party%3A+Atrophy+and+Adaptation&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+DC%3B+Berkeley%2C+CA&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-520-25492-3&amp;rft.aulast=Shambaugh&amp;rft.aufirst=David+L.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DaMpj-MboMR4C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span></li></ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Yi_Sun-sin" title="Yi Sun-sin">Yi Sun-sin</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Category:Science_and_technology_in_East_Asia" title="Category:Science and technology in East Asia">Science and technology</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Socialism_by_country" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Socialism_by_state" title="Template:Socialism by state"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Socialism_by_state" title="Template talk:Socialism by state"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Socialism_by_state&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Socialism_by_country" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">Socialism</a> by country</div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">By country</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="World_Trade_Organization" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:World_Trade_Organization" title="Template:World Trade Organization"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:World_Trade_Organization" title="Template talk:World Trade Organization"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:World_Trade_Organization&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="World_Trade_Organization" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a></div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">System</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovakia" title="Economy of Slovakia">Slovakia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovenia" title="Economy of Slovenia">Slovenia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Spain" title="Economy of Spain">Spain</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Sweden" title="Economy of Sweden">Sweden</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
</div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China</a>, participating as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao, China".</li>
<li>Officially the Republic of China, participates as "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu</a>", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.</li></ol>
<p><b><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="3002" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg/16px-The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg/24px-The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg/32px-The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:World" title="Portal:World">World portal</a></b>
</p>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Republic of Abkhazia</a>
